We invite you to join me and authors Rachel Page, Dina Dechmann, Teague O‚ÄôMara and Marco Tschapka, for a public webinar on Wed Dec 13 at 10am Panam√° time. Together, the five of us will discuss our newly published book, BAT ISLAND, taking you on a photographic journey to the rainforests of Barro Colorado Island, Panam√°, to meet the 76 species of bats that occupy this small space, and learn about their stunning natural history, physiology, evolution, sensory adaptations, foraging behavior, and social systems.
 
Join us on zoom at http://www.stri.si.edu/batisland

After years of anticipation, we're thrilled to present our bat book: ‚ÄòBAT ISLAND‚Äô, a tribute to our dear friend, Dr. Eli Kalko. Her visionary work in bat research set a remarkable course for many careers. Collaborating with exceptional authors - Dr. Rachel Page from STRI (Smithsonian Tropical Research Institute) @smithssonianbatlab, Dr. Dina Dechmann @DechmannLab (Max Planck Institute of Animal Behavior) @mpi_animalbehav , Dr. Marco Tschapka from the University of Ulm, and Dr. Teague O'Mara from Bat Conservation International - has been an incredible journey spanning two decades.

Our friendship with Eli and our shared passion for bats inspired this project. Over the last two decades, I've had the privilege of photographing the phenomenal and mysterious night flyers that continue to intrigue and inspire us.

The release of ‚ÄòBAT ISLAND‚Äô marks a milestone, sharing the captivating natural history, ecological insights, and social behavior of Barro Colorado Island's bats.

Published by Insight Editions, with authors from the Smithsonian Tropical Research Institute @smithsonianpanama, this book is an homage and testament to the profound legacy of Eli Kalko, and the impact she has had on tropical bat biology.

ü¶á Looking for the perfect Christmas gift? Look no further! üéÅ 'BAT ISLAND‚Äô is a treasure trove that captures the essence of these night flying wonders. With 160 pages of stunning imagery, BAT ISLAND delves into the captivating lives, diverse foraging habits, roosting secrets, and the fascinating social systems of Neotropical bats.

Ideal for both bat enthusiasts and inquisitive families, this book is more than just pages‚Äîit's an immersive experience into the lives of a remarkable group of animals. Whether exploring their nocturnal adventures or learning about their ecological importance, BAT ISLAND is an ideal gift to inspire awe and appreciation for the wonders of nature. Grab your copy now and gift the magic of bat exploration this holiday season! üåüü¶áüéÑ

Sharing a few more images of this remarkable moment when I encountered a bonobo with a young mongoose. 

I took all these images over about an hour as I watched this individual carry and play with a little mongoose, deep in the tropical forests of Democratic Republic of Congo. 

Big thanks to Dr. Barbara Fruth (Max-Planck Institute for Animal Behavior) and the team of the LuiKotale Bonobo Project for making these encounters possible. Follow me @christianziegler for more wildlife and nature photography!

Back from a very nice vacation, and I'm excited to share more Bonobo moments, starting with this incredible mongoose scene!

I am honored to have won the portrait category in 'Nature in focus' with this image ‚Äì thank you all for your support, especially the jury !

During my adventures near LuiKotale field station in the Democratic Republic of Congo I had a remarkable encounter. I witnessed a young male Bonobo tenderly petting a small mongoose.

This fascinating moment continued as he carefully held the mongoose while enjoying fruit in a nearby tree with the rest of his group.

However, this bond may not be as innocent as it seems. Bonobos occasionally include meat in their diet, and it's likely this young mongoose was caught when its mother was hunted by the group.

Big thanks to Dr. Barbara Fruth (Max-Planck Institute for Animal Behavior) and the team of the LuiKotale Bonobo Project for making these encounters possible. Follow me @christianziegler for more wildlife and nature photography!

Christopher Anderson - Family Trilogy

üìçL‚ÄôAppartement ‚Äì Espace Images Vevey
LES CHAMBRES

Christopher Anderson a commenc√© √† photographier sa famille de mani√®re quasiment organique d√®s la naissance de son fils Atlas en 2008. √Ä la naissance de sa fille Pia il poursuit cette qu√™te d‚Äôun p√®re essayant d‚Äôarr√™¬≠ter le temps, de ne laisser fuir aucun instant de sa nouvelle vie. Marion est omnipr√©sente dans ces albums √† la fois comme femme, m√®re et partenaire. En tant que photographe documentaire, Anderson n‚Äôavait jamais consid√©r√© ces photos personnelles comme une v√©ritable s√©rie, jusqu‚Äô√† ce que le photographe de guerre Tim Hetherington lui dise : ¬´ Il s‚Äôagit du temps qui passe ¬ª. Anderson a commenc√© √† voir ses images personnelles sous un nouveau jour et a fini par penser que ces photo¬≠graphies √©taient l‚Äôoeuvre de sa vie. Pia, Son et Marion ont √©t√© publi√©s en trois livres distincts, formant une trilogie familiale unique, tendre et intime.

- - -

Christopher Anderson naturally began photographing his family after his son Atlas came into the world in 2008. When his daughter Pia was born, he continued the fatherly attempt to stop time and not let a single moment of this new life slip away. Marion features throughout these albums, as a woman, mother, and partner. As a documentary photographer, Christopher Anderson had never considered these personal photos as a ‚Äòseries‚Äô, but his opinion changed when war photographer Tim Hetherington pointed out that ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre all about the passage of time.‚Äù Christopher Anderson began seeing his family pictures in a new light and realised that they may well be his best work. Pia, Son and Marion were published as three separate books, forming a unique and moving intimate family trilogy.

goodbye to a world
hello to a new one

is it a new year or a new day? the end of an era and the beginning of something new? the turning of a page or maybe the blur in between. moments you can read clearly followed by another blur, another page, repeat.

what are you taking with you into the new world? what are you leaving behind?
bend and not break
harvest.
isolated.

into the night ///
time for a story. I wanted to create with Inja for a long time. she‚Äôs an actress that moved to LA from Slovenia. super down to earth and fun to chat with, but also crazy expressive and emotional in front of the camera. an absolute dream to work with. she has so much energy and personality that you hardly have to direct, if at all. 

we got coffee way back when. for one reason or another, our schedules never lined up. finally, a couple years later we ended up dialing in a shoot. an adventure, rather. 

we snuck our way into this big historic apartment complex downtown LA. once we reached the top floor, we climbed out the window at the end of the hallway onto the fire escape. the first photo from the set is there. from there, the ladder to the top of the roof was really sketchy. it went up the side of the building about 20 feet, mind you we are 20 stories up. suddenly, something fell from her pocket... a neckless. I could hear it slipping through all the cracks of the metal escape. I asked her if it was valuable. her response, ‚Äúit was silver. my mother gave it to me. it‚Äôs ok though.‚Äù we kept climbing. 

read the rest of the story and see the full set with 50 photos and a whole lot of mood - uncensored on patreon.

which one is your favorite?
close your eyes, feel the light

My story about skiing in Caucasus Mountains in Georgia is live today on @natgeo! I am thrilled to finally share this series that I worked on last year. Traveling to Ushguli, which is protected by UNESCO, has been on my bucket list for a long time, and it‚Äôs one of those timeless places you can‚Äôt help but return to. Huge thanks to the amazing assistance of @shako_margiani and @maticek. Thanks also to great @natgeo team @rebekahbellbarlas and @maurafriedman. 

Please follow the link in my profile to read the story on @natgeo. I‚Äôll be sharing more from this trip in the coming days, so stay tuned.
#natgeo #skitouring #georgia #svaneti #ushguli #leica #leicaSL

My story about skiing in Caucasus Mountains in Georgia is live today on @natgeo! I am thrilled to finally share this series that I worked on last year. Traveling to Ushguli, which is protected by UNESCO, has been on my bucket list for a long time, and it's one of those timeless places you can't help but return to. Huge thanks to the amazing assistance of @shako_margiani and @maticek. 

Ushguli is considered the highest permanently inhabited point in Europe. According to the publicist Besarion Nizharadze, the name Ushguli, as a toponym, originates from 'fearless heart'. Thanks for great editing to photo editor @maurafriedman @natgeo. 

Please follow the link in my profile to read the story on @natgeo. I'll be sharing more from this trip in the coming days, so stay tuned.
#natgeo #skitouring #georgia #svaneti #ushguli #leica #leicaSL

‚ÄòWhat's the Correct Color of a Bee?‚Äô made the @nytimes list of top dispatches in 2023 and WON 1st honorable mention in the outstanding features category at the SEJ‚Äôs awards for reporting on the environment! ‚ú® SEJ - The Society of Environmental Journalists is association of professional journalists dedicated to more and better coverage of environment-related issues. It was great to work on this story with the incredible writer @denisehruby. The photographs were captured in Austrian's state of Carinthia, where the law favors light-colored local bees. @nytimes @sejournalists @boshnaqmona @adamjdean @leica_akademie_austria #nytimes #award #beekeepers #leica

I was incredibly fortunate to discover the Mre≈ænica River in Croatia last year while working on the River Champions campaign for @nature_org . The Mre≈ænica River is a natural gem, and we were privileged to collaborate with some remarkable and passionate individuals who really care about river conservation in the Balkans. @toorkish_coffee Asim Ugljen, a well known Croatian actor, kayaker and a father who loves spending time on the Mre≈ænica River shared his story with us. Thank you, Asim, for your time and inspiration.

Thanks also to Kre≈°o Rogoz @krogoz and @croatiaopenlandtoursfor logistic support and raft/kayak guidance. If you wish to explore the Mre≈ænica river do not hesitate to contact Kre≈°o to help you discover the river. @croatiaopenlandtours

The Western Balkans region is home to some of Europe‚Äôs last free-flowing rivers. There is a growing movement of people who are fighting to protect these unique ecosystems for generations to come. We were given the task to produce 8 short films about river champions and guardians, from scientists to locals who are trying to protect rivers in the Balkans.

#riverchampions #thenatureconservancy #unitedforrivers #tentfilm

I am honored to serve as a nominator for the LOBA 2024 once again. The Leica Oskar Barnack Award is one of the most important photography awards, and I will never forget when I received this  recognition in 2013. We are actively seeking bodies of work centered around the theme of the relationship between humans and their environment.

If you believe you have a compelling and relevant series, please feel free to send me an email at ciril@tentfilm.com, including your work and an artistic statement. Additionally, you are welcome to tag someone whom you believe deserves this recognition. 

Attached are some photos from my LOBA-winning series 'Waiting to Move,' captured during my expedition to Shishmaref, Sarichef Island, Alaska. The purpose of this journey was to document the effects of climate change on the lives of the InÃÉupiat people.
@leica_camera @leica_camera_austria

Hope you have a heartfelt holiday wherever you are and close to the people you care about. We live in a fast-changing, unpredictable world with so much imbalance and unfairness. Thinking of those who are not so lucky to live in peace or without a roof over their heads. Here is a clip from a recent trip to Northwest of Greenland where I work on a new documentary project with @insidenatgeo National Geographic Society.  #MerryChristmas

I've spent a few days in NYC attending the screening of my film 'Dream to Cure Water.' There was unique winter light and I just has to do some street photography. It's all about breaking the ice with a simple question: "May I take your picture?" Allow me to introduce Olivia, a medical student and photographer, whom I encountered near the Meatpacking District. All these were taken with the Leica M11 and 50mm Summilux-M. @leica_camera_austria @lairdandgoodcompany

When my body feels off the best thing I‚Äôve learned is to become my biggest advocate! For me it‚Äôs a combination of checking in with the professionals and experts , taking that information, and doing a deep dive into reading/doing my research on how I can support my body the most. This is incredibly empowering to learn our bodies and what the body needs. A lot of times it is not one solve, but a lifestyle change that needs to happen. It does take extra work, but you‚Äôd be surprised how we can become our own healers!

Our little Rowen Lily met her namesake and Abuelitaü§ç
Ryan and I were back and forth with Rowen‚Äôs middle name up until a week before she made her grand entrance. One night I looked at Ryan and we said‚Ä¶ she HAS to have my mom‚Äôs name. 
My mama has the strength like no other and has successfully raised 6 strong daughters. She has hung in there with such grace, as the awful disease of dementia has robbed her of so much. No other name would be fitting, as my mama has heard every dream, every worry, every hope for our little baby as she grew in our surrogates safe belly all while facing her biggest battle. My hope for my daughter, it‚Äôs to be just as strong and resilient as her Abuelitaü§ç

We are officially one week old today!! üíï
My little Rowen is everything I‚Äôve dreamed of, and truly it‚Äôs hard to imagine life before her. She is the most mellow sweet baby, and my little ray of sunshine! Working on her birth story to share with you guys but for now we are just soaking in all the yumminess of her! ü•∞

The Ford GT90 Concept Car 

Unveiled in 1995 to celebrate Ford's 90th anniversary and honor the iconic GT40, the Ford GT90 concept car was a bold statement of automotive innovation. It housed a potent quad-turbocharged 6.0-liter V12 engine generating up to 720 horsepower. 

It included advanced features like carbon fiber construction, traction control, and active suspension, the GT90 boasted impressive performance figures, reportedly hitting a top speed of 253 mph (407 km/h) and achieving 0-60 mph in just 3.1 seconds. Despite its acclaim, the GT90 never saw production, serving as a testament to Ford's boundary-pushing engineering and design capabilities.

Rumor has it that only one GT90 Concept Car was ever made, and it currently resides at the Hajek Motorsports Museum in Ames, Oklahoma.

‚ÄúCan you swim?‚Äù

The Lotus Esprit S1, famously known as ‚ÄòWet Nellie‚Äô holds a significant place as one of the most iconic cars in the James Bond film franchise. Although six different Lotus S1s were utilized during filming, only one underwent modifications by Perry Oceanographic, an American marine equipment company. While the car itself couldn‚Äôt actually transform into a submarine, a submersible version was specially crafted for all underwater scenes.

In a notable turn of events, in 2013, Elon Musk acquired the submersible version for $997,000, expressing his intention to transform it into a functional submersible car.

Presenting the Porsche 993 ‚ÄúTarga‚Äù Carrera 2 reimagined by @Kreinzel

This bespoke Porsche 993 was meticulously crafted from the ground up with over ‚Ç¨300,000 invested solely in new Porsche parts. It was built on the foundation of an original Porsche 993 Carrera 2 and is eligible for registration worldwide. 

With only one in existence and less than 350km on the odometer, this is a rare opportunity to own a truly unique Porsche 993. It features a 3.6L flat-six engine capable of 315hp and is equipped with a 4-piston sport braking system, 18‚Äù Fuchs wheels, Clubsport exhaust system, adjustable suspension, and exclusive Recaro sport/comfort seats. Other amenities include a GPS, Bluetooth, a high-fidelity sound system, and a customized full leather interior. 

This build currently resides in Portugal with worldwide delivery options and maintenance available at any certified Porsche dealer/service center. For those eager to own this exceptional vehicle, be sure to reach out to @Kreinzel to learn more.

One of the most exciting shoots I did last year was working with the @eastafricanreptiles & Taylor Ashe Antivenom center in Watamu, Kenya to photograph spitting cobras. This particular snake is a Red Spitting Cobra (Naja pallida). Photographing these snakes is a challenge because they are not only highly venomous but they can be very aggressive/defensive as well. I had to wear a full face shield, which allowed me to avoid getting any of the venom they spit in my eyes, nose or ears.

Snakes are sadly often misunderstood and killed on sight no matter the circumstance, which is horrible because they are such a vital part of the eco systems we all live in. Organizations like East Africa Reptile's focus much of their attention not only on education and safety,  but in helping to safely remove snakes from people's homes and properties around Kenya, further increasing their chances of survival.

Sony a7R V w/ 90mm f/2.8 Macro Lens + 2 @godox_global V860 III OCF Units

This is one of the most unique looking frogs you can find in Costa Rica, known as the Coronated Tree Frog. It's name comes from the fact that at certain angles, it looks as if it is wearing a crown. They can be found in the mountains around the area known as Sarapique, just north of San Jose. It is one of many different species of frogs and snakes that we look for during my Costa Rica wildlife workshops I run each January.

Last September I found myself wandering around the deserts of Dubai in search of the Horned Arabian Viper. Unfortunately for me, it was the wrong time of year as they tend to love the hot desert nights. We did however find a number of these Saw Scaled Vipers (Echis Carinatus). These beautiful snakes are easily the most deadly snake in the UAE, accounting for more snake bites per year than all other snakes combined. They can be aggressive, have a quick strike and a very powerful venom.

Thanks to @wildlifewithnitin for showing me around! Can't wait for the next adventure!

Happy National Margarita Day! üç∏ This Italian Margarita recipe with limoncello will transport you straight to the Amalfi coast! üáÆüáπ As the self-proclaimed margarita queen, it‚Äôs no secret that I love dreaming up different margarita variations. Whether you celebrate this holiday with an Italian marg, a spicy marg, or an old faithful, I hope you enjoy it to the fullest (alongside some nachos, of course)! ü•Ç

Ingredients:
1 oz¬†fresh lime juice
1 oz¬†fresh¬†blood orange juice (or pomegranate juice if not in season)
1 oz¬†limoncello
2 oz¬†blanco tequila
Club soda, top top (optional)

Instructions:
1. Fill a cocktail shaker with ice and add in lime juice, blood orange juice, limoncello and tequila. Shake for 20-30 seconds or until the cocktail shaker is well chilled.¬†
2. Pour into a low glass with ice, top with club soda if desired and garnish with a blood orange slice.

#NationalMargaritaDay #margarita #italianmargarita #amalfi #amalficoast

Super Easy 4 Ingredient peanut butter cookies! üç™ Crispy golden edges, gooey peanut butter centers. Bookmark these for your next sweet tooth!¬†

PEANUT BUTTER COOKIES:¬†
1 ¬Ω cups smooth peanut butter¬†
1 ¬Ω cups brown sugar¬†
2 large eggs, at room temp
1 ¬Ω tsp baking soda¬†
1 tsp vanilla paste, optional¬†

Instructions:¬†

1. Preheat the oven to 350 F. Line two medium rimmed baking sheets with parchment paper and set aside.¬†
2. In a bowl with a stand mixer or a medium bowl with a hand mixer add peanut butter and brown sugar. Mix together on medium-high for 2-3 minutes.¬†
3. Add eggs, baking soda and vanilla bean paste if using and mix together for another minute.¬†
4. With a 1 inch cookie scoop, scoop dough balls onto the baking sheet and create a criss cross pattern with a fork. Top with a little extra brown sugar if desired.¬†
5. Bake for 8-9 minutes or until the edges are slightly golden brown. Remove from the oven and leave on the baking sheet for an additional 3-5 minutes. Transfer to a wire baking rack to finish cooling.

Climbing brings us together.  Once you challenge yourself with gravity and share this experience with your friends something changes. It's the international language of belaying and spotting. It's the same everywhere. You have to trust someone to achieve your goals. 

@memphisroxclimbing has been a flywheel for the good that climbing brings. Built in the shell of a supermarket with a state of the facility, Rox is bringing gym climbing and outdoor experiences to South Memphis.

With a pay as one can model, the gym is open to everyone. Climbing as I was introduced to it was free. The cliffs were at  end of the road and my dad and his buddies had the gear and knowledge. I still recall the moment when climbing and being outdoors latched on. It's that same emotion that we see with the people we welcome to the crag, mountain and gym. Let's keep that going! 

The freedom that climbing brings comes at a cost. The facility and staff are monthly obligations. In business, as in climbing, the unexpected happens. In this case a burst water pipe needs immediate attention. To keep Rox a safe place (it's a polling station, health care facility and restaurant) the security team needs immediate funding. Going without costs the program more. 

Rox has been a part of my life for the past six years. I've made new friends, shared backcountry experience & knowledge while climbing outdoors and learned from each other on how to address the challenges of race in the United States. 

If you believe in the mission of @memphisroxclimbing please consider a donation. It will be put to good use. If you have the chance to visit Memphis, stop by the gym. You'll find family by the time you have warmed up.

#thankyou

30 years ago today,  the last day of the year,  @johnmiddendorf4 and I climbed Cerro Torre, Patagonia via the Compressor Route. (South East Ridge) Established in 1970 by Cesare Maestri with a gasoline powered drill, the controversial route sported a stack of bolts and was the quick way to the top. 

John and I enjoyed the climb,  yet these was something amiss. The wildness of this peak was sacrificed for human ego. Maestri, making up for his fanciful ascent of 1959, bolted the peak into submission. 
 
In 2012 the late Hayden Kennedy and 
@jason_kruk removed the bolts, giving the mountain its power back and creating controversy.

If Cerro Torre is a peak that you are interested in please listen to @climbinggold. The recent season includes the Maestri Mystery with insight from @kellycordes, author of "The Tower", the definitive book on this subject.

In reviewing my journal from 30 years ago I reflect on how climbing has changed. Even if we have better weather  forecasts and lighter & stronger gear, the sense of self discovery one gets from a proper Patagonian beat down still remains. This primal connection to living is as real as it gets. 

First photo of the Cerro Torro group from the summit of Chalten by Galen Rowell.

Kyle Allen Rott 1987 - 2023 
On  November  25th we lost Kyle in a fall in Hyalite Canyon, Montana. My heart goes out to his mother and sister and the South Dakota family of this fine man.  For his friends the loss is immediate. The years of being together,  weaving the fabric of friendship through shared experiences are gone.

Kyle was a climber. Once he realized that the pursuit of gravity was his life's calling,  he lived with a singular purpose. "Let's go climb."

As someone close to Kyle, his "uncle" by age and knowing him with our family, his loss is another weight on the scale of "is it worth it".

Many of my close friends are introverts. In school we found each other and climbing self selected us. Kyle and I climbed together for 15 years - most of the time hiking the folds of Southwest Montana looking for the cliffs and drips that sustain us. In between climbs he helped out by housesitting for the climbing community. For those of that trusted Kyle without houses and animals - you know how conscientious he was.  Kyle's humble approach to life - not entertaining anything superfluous - was reflected by living in his truck.  Which made housesitting a good balance. 

While Kyle was quiet and shy in a room of his peers, there was this friendly side that Kyle shared with people in life. More than once he would carefully explain the gadgets needed to climb to curious people on the trail. This translated well to the guiding he did with Montana Alpine Guides and the Mountain School in Yosemite. 

At our service for Kyle we wrote in a small book for his mother and family. His worldly possessions, kept tidy in a Livingston storage locker, spread out over a picnic table, passed to his friends. They will cherish his memory and then ply the seas of gravity, risking it all for the moment. For his age peers, dealing with non sequential death, many for the first time, left adrift questioning and bonding closer with those that stand. I was there. And now 30 years later as an elder, with culpability and responsibility.

We love you Kyle for energy you brought to our climbing adventures. 

We love you for the reminder to live calm. 

Photos @petetapley

Stand in solidarity with Alaska‚Äôs Indigenous communities, advocate for clean water and connected ecosystems and urge them to select the ‚ÄúNo Action Alternative.‚Äù 

The Ambler industrial road is a 211-mile corridor across the western Brooks Range that would risk loosing North America‚Äôs largest ecologically connected area to endless open pit mining and development. It would cross 1200 rivers and streams, disrupt the migration of the Western Arctic
caribou herd, slice through Gates of the Arctic National Preserve and dismantle the subsistence livelihood of at least 66 communities. 

Seventy-four tribes and First Nations on the Yukon River watershed, 37 tribal governments in the Tanana Chiefs Conference, 23 Yupik tribes, 10 Inupiaq tribal governments, and five Athabascan tribes
closest to the road corridor all have standing resolutions in opposition to this disastrous development project.

The Biden Administration and the Bureau of Land Management have the authority to revoke permits and end it‚Äôs trajectory forward. 

Please submit your comment now before the public comment period is closed on Dec. 22, and tell the Bureau of Land Management NO to the Ambler industrial road.
@noamblerroad @defendbrooksrange  #noamble

Big love to this guy, my dear dear friend Reinaldo Marcus Green for his new film One Love @onelovemovie out in theaters now. I don‚Äôt know how many times I‚Äôve talked about the importance of lighting throughout my career. Too many. Which is it‚Äôs so funny that Rei and I met in Lamps Plus on some random Tuesday (that‚Äôs Rei‚Äôs review on the last slide)

Biopics are notoriously hard films to make, especially when the person depicted is still fresh in our memory. Covering an entire life and weaving it all together is an incredibly difficult task. It‚Äôs arguable that Bob Marley is the most globally recognizable musician in the world. His music is pervasive and I‚Äôve heard it everywhere I‚Äôve traveled, from an international science station in Antarctica to a boat in the Russian Arctic to a tea house in Tibet. Few contemporary artists have such a fingerprint and I believe his message is important now more than ever.

It‚Äôs hard to comprehend the undertaking of Rei, Kingsley Ben-Adir, Lashana Lynch @lashanalynch and everyone else involved in the film. Regardless, under his direction, the roles are transformative and played with incredible skill and care. Well done! Go have some popcorn and let the music you already know be born again.

The curb weight of the Porsche 356, the first Porsche automobile, was 1700 ‚Äì 2,296 lbs. The weight of the Porsche name is much heavier. Ferdinand ‚ÄòFerdi‚Äô Porsche, an architect by trade and the great grandson of the company‚Äôs founder Prof. Ferdinand Porsche, is now adding his fingerprint to the family‚Äôs rich motor-sports legacy.

At 30 yrs old, Ferdi defies all the seriousness and pomp of racing cars. He‚Äôs affable, warm, and almost boyish in his excitement. To put it bluntly, he‚Äôs ‚Äòcool‚Äô without effort, working hard to invite the next generation into the motorsports world.

 On February 24, Ferdi‚Äôs F.A.T. International held its first ice race in Zell am See, Austria, and has followed it up in Aspen, Colorado. Over the past two days on an icy track in Carbondale, the race has included models from the @aetherapparel Half11 (half Porsche, half F1) to the Rivian R1T, to a host of various Mobil 1 cars tearing around corners, over-steering, under-steering, and generally bringing joy as they spit rooster tails of snow from their tires. 

I watch as an enthusiast warm his hands in the exhaust of a loud engine. He brings them to his nose, closes his eyes and inhales deeply, letting his senses coalesce into something whole and visceral. Ferdi sits in his car nearby grinning. It‚Äôs an expression of sincere, palpable joy. As an arm drops, he accelerates onto the track. In a burst of exhaust, something old becomes new again. It‚Äôs a Herculean task and these are enormous shoes to fill, but Ferdi seems to be carrying the weight of legacy effortlessly.

A little handful of some of the best drivers around. Amazing to watch the talent of these four @mobil1racing athletes at the @fat.international @fat.icerace over the past two days‚Ä¶and just as fun to be able to photograph them. Big thanks to @aetherapparel as well for the support.

1: Stephane Ortelli
@stephaneortelli

Words by Ben Ayers @jetbutterflies // In the wide desert of Upper Mustang, the road planes along canyon walls and dry mountainsides dotted with hundreds of unspeakably ancient human-made caves. The light plays a slow game of chase with the shadows cast by the highest mountains on the planet, now behind us. We sweep the corners wide, drawn to cliff-edges teetering above the braided Kali Gandaki River below. We don‚Äôt know where to look ‚Äì the road, the layers of tortured mountains, or the sand-castle parapets of rock and mud towering above us.
 
Instead, we watch the oncoming frame-bent jeeps as they roaring around the blind corners on bald tires. In Tsarang, the drivers share a rough kindness with us. We play snooker, a game we don‚Äôt know. Cory tries and fails to find a tutorial on YouTube. Nursing warm cans of beer, we realize the drivers don‚Äôt know how to play either.
 
The evening passes in one long, impossible game of scratches and flubs until the young man running the hall flicks the light switch and kicks us out into the cold, thin air of a star-streaked night.  @vacheronconstantin

Our hearts remain with the thousands of families that have lost loved ones in the 6.4 magnitude earthquake in West Nepal. As winter approaches, tens of thousands remain without adequate shelter or warmth. If you‚Äôd like to contribute please visit Blinknow.org - these are friends of ours working tirelessly on the ground, and every contribution matters.

We will resume our Mustang travelogue starting today to celebrate all the beauty, resiliency, and magic of Nepal in the faith that if we all work together, brighter days will come soon. // following words by @jetbutterflies Hoping for mountains, we find fog. Climbing towards Sarangkot, the city disappears behind us. Marigolds line the road that falls away into steeped terraces dotted by clusters of roughhewn homes. An hour in, we find the main highway again, paved and twisted into tight curls across the steep hillsides like a pig‚Äôs tail. Todd‚Äôs back wheel blows up, death-wobbling him across the narrow road and directly into a stable of split-open motor scooters under a corrugated tin roof held together with wire.

The mechanic opens the rear tire, and leaves the parts strewn across the shoulder of the highway. A metal-handled hammer and broken screwdriver finish the job: a blown bearing. The mechanic isn‚Äôt much of a talker. He saddles a scooter and buzzes off to somewhere while the town gathers around us, sharing stories and children and a, most proudly, new iPhone 12 ProMax.  They return with two bearings ‚Äì ‚ÄúJapan‚Äù brand. ‚ÄúBest quality‚Äù, he says.
Four hours of riding to go. @vacheronconstantin @aetherapparel

In these crucial first days after the quake, rescue efforts give way to the critical, and complex, process of providing impacted communities with food, warmth, and shelter.  Rebuilding takes time, but helping provide these basic needs can make a tremendous difference in the long run.

@maggiedoyne and @blinknoworg are on the ground at the epicenter and are focusing their efforts on vulnerable groups like pregnant women,  and the most isolated communities that are typically the last to receive aid. 

Supporting their work is the best way you can help from afar. Donations of every size matter.  Nepal has given us both so much, please help us in our efforts to give a tiny bit of that back when it matters the most.

http://www.blinknow.org/earthquake
üì∑ @rushsturges @coryrichards

The thing about earthquakes is that they impact poor and vulnerable communities the most. Those who can‚Äôt afford to reinforce their homes, or who don‚Äôt have a surplus of resources like family, income, or grain to weather months of rebuilding and trauma.

In light of the recent 6.4 magnitude earthquake that struck Western Nepal last night - just miles from Mustang - and our hope to focus public attention on supporting relief efforts, we will postpone our travelogue until next week.

Currently, there are 150+ known deaths from the quake with many hundreds more injured and tens of thousands left without shelter as winter approaches. Please watch this space for updates on how you can help the families in Jajarkot and Rukum recover and build back better.

With love, 
Cory and Ben

MAD MAX
 
Words by Ben Ayers @jetbutterflies // The highway is a perpetual a fever dream of construction and destruction. Dust, scattered pavement, clawed ridges of clay are punctuated with the idle carcasses of heavy equipment, thin herds of goats, and garish tractors bouncing between knee-deep ruts. When you don‚Äôt have any lanes, you‚Äôre always splitting lanes.
 
Six days ago, Cory did what any responsible motorcyclist would do: he watched a YouTube video titled ‚ÄúHow to Ride a Motorcycle in ONLY 1 HOUR,‚Äù which, it turns out, was only twenty minutes long. 
 
Cory then traced the backstreets of Santa Monica on a tiny caf√© racer for five days before boarding a plane for Kathmandu. Now, eight hours of riding on Nepal‚Äôs worst and busiest highway later, the sun collapses across rice paddies heavy with grain. We still have hours to go.
 
In this perpetual present, when you‚Äôre gripped, you experience the relativity of time. It slows to a game of seconds until, as if by magic, hours have passed.

I‚Äôve known Ben Ayers @jetbutterflies for over a decade. He‚Äôs a Kathmandu staple and has called Nepal home for twenty some years. He came for the mountains and stayed for the people, starting and running non-profits for pieces of the community. At his heart, he‚Äôs an artist and filmmaker. He‚Äôs also a ferocious writer. I‚Äôve been to Mustang with him before on assignment for NG. But this trip is just for us. The following posts are his words.
 
Our other companion is Todd Hoffman. He doesn‚Äôt use Instagram. He‚Äôs one of those leather-faced legends of the eighties who lived hard and fast enough to know when to leave the racetrack. Even if you hardly know him, you want him on your team. At your back. If he looks familiar, it might be from that one time he took Pepsi to task over a Harrier jump jet.
 
The following posts are from our motorcycle trip from Kathmandu to Lo Manthang. @vacheronconstantin @aetherapparel

RECEITA: TORTILLA DE PATATAS

Um cl√°ssico espanhol da Catalunha. Um omelet√£o de batatas e muito azeite de oliva.

Pode servir em fatias grandes com salada, ou servir em cima de fatias de p√£o e algum complemento em cima. Assim os espanh√≥is chamam de Pintxos.

Obs:

_A medida √© 2 pra 1, dois ovos pra cada batata.

_Cozinhe as batatas em muito azeite de oliva antes de fazer a tortilla. Depois voc√™ vai escorrer e guardar o azeite para usar em outras receitas, √© √≥timo.

_O jeito espanhol √© cozinhar de um lado, virar e cozinhar do outro, o que exige uma certa t√©cnica. D√° pra usar aquelas omeleteiras que tem duas frigideiras que se encaixam. E tamb√©m d√° pra terminar o cozimento no forno, por√©m precisa de uma frigideira que vai ao forno.

Descasque as batatas, corte ao meio e fatie-as. Se tiver um mandolim, perfeito, sen√£o pode fazer na faca. Fatie a cebola tamb√©m.

Coloque as batatas e cebolas em uma frigideira antiaderente cubra com azeite, suficiente para que elas fiquem quase submersas. Leve ao fogo e cozinhe, sem ferver loucamente, at√© que as batatas estejam macias, mas n√£o desmanchando. Retire do fogo, espere esfriar um pouco e escorra. Guarde o azeite em uma garrafa.

Em uma tigela grande bata os ovos e adicione as batatas mornas. Tempere com uma pitada de sal e misture bem. Deixe descansar por 15 minutos.

Na mesma frigideira, adicione umas colheradas do azeite, aque√ßa no fogo m√©dio e despeje a mistura. Cozinhe at√© que a parte de baixo esteja bem dourada. A parte de cima ainda vai estar meio l√≠quida. 

Para terminar o cozimento:
No forno: pr√©- aquecido a 180¬∫C por uns 10 a 15 minutos.
Na frigideira: deslize a tortilla para um prato grande, coloque a frigideira em cima e vire de uma vez. Termine de cozinhar at√© o outro lado ficar dourado tamb√©m.

Retire, deixe descansar e sirva em temperatura ambiente.

Para servir como pintxos, corte em quadradinhos, finalize com as azeitonas, piment√µes e jam√≥n e coloque sobre fatias de baguete. Como prato principal, corte em fatias e sirva com uma salada.

BODY BOOKWORM / SOMATIC SCHOLAR 

During the time I‚Äôve been with my husband my body has seen many changes. Seemingly subtle ones that speak loud as women‚Äôs bodies do in all our many stages. These are changes that a superficial mind conditioned by a skin-deep culture would label as not attractive. I remember my EX-husband being disgusted by my armpit & random nipple hairs which I thought was hilarious, after all women have testosterone helping us produce new blood cells, maintain bone health, libido & boost other reproductive hormones. I‚Äôve been learning more about hormone changes as I approach menopause which is incredibly fascinating & always reiterates to me how wise the body is in adapting throughout its phases. 

The body is a book that reads of its lifetime. Birthmarks, scars, aging marks, wrinkles, tattoos, spots, hair loss, stretch marks, some of us lose limbs or gain ‚Äúextra‚Äù parts along the journey. The book of the body is beautiful in its creativity. It tells a rich story. Looking at a dead body is captivating in a way, being that the soul has left its shell. It‚Äôs like an artifact left behind with stories of the past written on its skin. A tangible object the soul crafted while here on earth. But the beauty of an alive body is that the soul is still inhabited & can continue to write. Creating until its very last day. I want my body to be a museum when my soul leaves it. 

Often my clients are surprised that I know so many intimate details about their inner world without them having to tell me.  They say ‚Äúhow did you know that?‚Äù ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs like you‚Äôre inside me!‚Äù ‚ÄúYou were saying what I was thinking as I was thinking it! How do you know that?‚Äù Well, I‚Äôve read a lot of bodies in my lifetime & it‚Äôs my gift (one could say). I‚Äôm a body bookworm or a somatic scholar. The beauty of the way the body reads is that it doesn‚Äôt lie like the mind does. It‚Äôs vulnerable (even if you think you‚Äôre not). It‚Äôs incapable of lying; just like an aged body cannot look young no matter how hard you or your plastic surgeon try to turn back time. That‚Äôs what I find stunning about aging & my work as a somatic healer. It‚Äôs honest AF & the Scorpio in me doesn‚Äôt do casual or roundabout.

I was asked if I could talk about my positive mindset towards aging: 

The older I get the smaller my ego becomes. As the persona dies I embrace my authentic self/true essence more (what people describe as ‚Äúmore comfortable in your own skin‚Äù).Not placing so much attention on the superficial I have loads of time/mind/energy space to be without the ‚Äúnoise‚Äù. It‚Äôs an ALWAYS VACATION. But most of my comfort is directly linked to my comfort with death. The reason our culture is so afraid of getting old is because they are afraid of death. So we don‚Äôt talk about death, we talk about aging when we should be talking about death. 

There are many reasons why people fear death. Where do we go? What happens? We imagine the worst. There are those (including myself) that have had near death experiences & have crossed the veil which gives us a sneak peek into the other-side BUT unless you know someone that was straight dead & has come back to share the mystery‚Ä¶ The mystery remains & that‚Äôs what freaks people out & fascinates me so. Our brains are wired to reduce uncertainty & death is the epitome of uncertainty which is why life‚Äôs greatest practice is to get comfortable with the uncomfortable which in essence is practicing death. 

But think of it in this way; Look at history & our current world. War. Pain. Struggle. Hurt. Greed. Violence. It‚Äôs all fucked. And we think the other-side is scary?! That makes me LOL! Life isn‚Äôt easy & it‚Äôs purposefully designed that way! The longer you live the more of a chance you get to get comfortable with the uncomfortable, that means embracing aging (death). That is if you understand that‚Äôs what life is for. If you don‚Äôt aging will become the living death you fear & it will become your reality. The more you repress the process the more the fear virus will spread within you. The more you embrace it the more ‚Äúlife‚Äù you get.

ANNIVERSARY 5

2yrs into a divorce that crushed my spirit & stole the ground from underneath me I was finally coming out of the biggest inner battle of my life. I was starting to feel ‚Äúin my body‚Äù again, content in my celibacy & happy to stay solo for the rest of my life so of course the universe throws unconditional love at me via the sexiest vessel I‚Äôd ever seen. ‚ÄúHis name is Ruben. He‚Äôs made for you. Take it or leave it‚Äù said the Universe. Oh I took it (for a day üòú)& then I left it, answering back to the universe ‚Äúif you want me to take it FOREVER you‚Äôll show me the way‚Äù. 

FUK ME if she did! 9 months after meeting him I moved from the üá∫üá∏‚û°Ô∏èüáµüáπ. 3 months later we were married & bought our 1st apartment. Today married 5yrs. The wedding had at the local municipality in flip flops & converse followed up with a√ßa√≠ at our favorite spot. That ease & comfort continues to guide us through the healthiest, happiest, most passionate relationship ever possible! 

I didn‚Äôt want to get married again nor was I looking for a soulmate. I was focused on getting me back after being completely obliterated in my ex-marriage. I fed myself all the love & by that I mean I got down, dirty, ugly & real. I faced every face of my-self & took responsibility (ACTION)! 

When my mind-spirit-body got healthy-happy on my own dime I was able to reflect healthy-happy back into the world. You see, Ruben had been doing the work as well before meeting me. If we had met even a month before the most magical day of our lives the universe would have said ‚ÄúNope. Keep at it kids.‚Äù That‚Äôs why searching for love in another without the doing the self-work doesn‚Äôt work. Find IT in yourself & the love will reflect back NATURALLY. The beauty is that the love will reflect back FOREVER with EASE because it is based in honesty & respect from the root of where it began‚Ä¶ in you. 

Te amo @offcina.movimento. Por siempre para sempre

Take care of your vessel, or as I like to call the body‚û°Ô∏èour spaceships üöÄ that help us travel to infinity and beyond. Take care of it and it will take care of you. A reminder that love heals all ways. ‚ù§Ô∏è

I was talking to a man the other day & his eyes kept skimming over to a huge patch of gray hair growing strong from my roots. Fascinating watching his thoughts as he kept the casual conversation going with his eyes fixed on my gray. I heard my inner voice say ‚Äúcool ol‚Äô lady huh?‚Äù 

I‚Äôve been completely mesmerized by my beauty as I age. I say this not in vanity but in the sheer wonderment of watching my body slowly decay. I find the life to death cycle absolutely stunning; not only in humans but in all organisms. The way my skin has softened, age spots appearing, lips thinned, the wrinkle between my brow more pronounced, neck sagging‚Ä¶. goodness it‚Äôs fucking sexy! Nothing more beautiful to me than a woman who lounges in her skin with confidence & pleasure. I wouldn‚Äôt go back to my youth if you paid me! With every new chin hair that grows thicker I celebrate my life! 

The beauty of getting older besides the obvious of giving zero fucks is that I‚Äôm 100% involved in every change that happens in my body. The changes are bigger & more frequent, the body has a lots more opinions on how it‚Äôs treated & it too gives zero fucks when it comes to showing off it‚Äôs age: trigger finger, rotator cuffs tears, pre-menopausal aches & sweats, random old funky surprises that make me say, ‚Äúnow what!?‚Äù 

It‚Äôs always something & the recovery rate a lot slower BUT it forces my ass to get up & go on a long walk, jogs, resistance training, stretching, hot/cold therapy, healthy diet, emotional somatic cleansing MovMEANT EVERY SINGLE DAY! I know without this type of discipline I will break down much faster! The Olympian in me digs hard on the challenge. 

I don‚Äôt fear death. I highly respect it, as much as I respect life. For that reason I cherish my time on earth & when I die I‚Äôd like to go OLD. REALLY OLD. So old they think I‚Äôm already dead yet I can rock a solid pull up üòÇ 

Old is a privilege. Respect. üëµüèº

(OF)Original Foundation. Your birth real estate. The initial structure you learned to build from. How sturdy did it prove? How have the foundational teachings come to hurt or help you now? You see this video ‚¨ÜÔ∏è This was a big part of my OF. Started at 5yrs old. Olympian by 15. Professional dancer in my 20‚Äôs & 30‚Äôs. Somatic healing from 5 to my current 47. Discipline is the greatest tool I learned from the foundational teaching of my somatic ‚Äúcareer‚Äù. THE DISCIPLINE never allowed the healing & connection to body-self stray for too long. I always returned to it one way or another either by choice or necessity. MovMEANT isn‚Äôt something I do any longer to impress or for ego. It‚Äôs my fucking sanity, the original foundation planted from day one! It could give 2fucks if it looks good or if I do it the ‚Äúright‚Äù way. It‚Äôs no longer for vanity. In fact nothing about me is. Life has a way of conditioning us (particularly women, women athletes, women in the entertainment industry as I was all of those) that we have to look, be, move a certain way. It took me a long time to uncondition myself from all the BS. I‚Äôm loving my grays & the way my neck skin gets soft & wobbles when I turn my neck. If you‚Äôre not wobbly & wiggly something ain‚Äôt right! Point being, the original foundation still holds this ol‚Äô ship up solid even if the seas are turbulent. Everybody‚Äôs foundation holds wisdom. You just gotta write & live by the narrative that serves best. I could choose to see my narrative as the athlete as the little girl who starved & survived emotional & psychological abuse, or I could see it as the beastmode warrior that never let anyone fuck with her spirit & always stayed true to her authenticity while getting some serious gains. I choose the second & that helps me thrive even today. 

üáµüáπMovMEANT.com for online classes, private sessions & 2024 October intensive in portugal.

FOX

SHE. The savage one. Wild, raw, ferocious, untamed. That which she is & always was. That no experience or other can take from her for it is her blood. Cut her open and the fox will come out to play; mischievous, adaptable, playful, resilient, clever. SHE is the one THEY fear yet admire from afar as she dances in her unabashed freedom. Judge her and you will only reflect your own fears. Watch her for a while and she will make you scold away any bit of repression. Words like ugly, pretty, crazy, sexy, stupid are just but passing sound waves to dance too. Names are one dimensional. Stories are boring. Labels are the illusion that anything can be defined. Presence is potent and potency is her magic. It‚Äôs all an open void she can paint expression and movement vomit on. Her most intimate companion is her mortality. The acknowledgement of her death allows her to live unabashed NOW. SHE is in all of us, just for most she‚Äôs hidden by a veil of fear. Drop the veil so the fox can play free.

CREATIVITY IS THE GREATEST HEALING TOOL

I give a lot of credit to my creativity in terms of my healing abilities in myself & in guiding others. Creativity is the greatest facet to human intelligence & consciousness. There‚Äôs no greater tool than creativity when it comes to EVERYTHING. 

Just look at the world we‚Äôve created through our creativity. We generate all sorts of new ideas, continual advancement, solve all sorts of problems & make phenomenal works of art that move us, connect us & help us express & communicate the wordless parts of us. Yet I‚Äôve found that when it comes to healing trauma, reconnecting energetically, getting past our emotional wounds, the power of creativity gets overlooked or even laughed at. 

The brain says ‚Äúwhy are we playing around making art when you‚Äôre in pain?‚Äù Well brain to answer your question: because through abstract expression & creative sourcing I discombobulate your narrative & give myself an outlet of energy, thus giving IT a voice instead of you continuously reciting the same ol‚Äô wack narrative that keeps me stuck! 

Creativity is empowering. The fearful brain doesn‚Äôt want you playing around with new ideas. It wants you safe & sound staying in its ‚Äúknown‚Äù state so it doesn‚Äôt have to be left in some weird unknown where it can‚Äôt ‚Äúprotect‚Äù you. But the body wants to express itself freely. They both have good intentions & find themselves disagreeing. The brain is the more careful fearful parent; the body the free-spirited parent. The compromise is in creativity. Safe enough for the brain, adventurous enough for the body, giving you TONS of options on how to approach the problem(s). 

Where we tend to get stuck in our healing is that we always go the same route, ending up at the same point. Creativity gives you different routes, new scenery, new possibilities, different end points. A huge part of my practice & work with my clients is focused on creativity. How can we give the same old story a boost & reboot? How can we turn the boring old mind dance into a new & exciting vibrant masterpiece? MovMEANT.com for a whole new perspective on healing.

THE VEIL

Do you know the true expression of your voice? 

Have you heard it sing at the top of its lungs without a care in the world. Heard it laugh exuberantly to the point where your belly hurts so good. Has your true expression rolled around in the grass playfully, danced wild in the fields, cried without apology, sat in emotion without blame or judgement, spoken truth vulnerably, felt the feels, voiced its needs, stopped apologizing for being who you are where you are. 

Your true expression isn‚Äôt a privilege, it‚Äôs a need. Repressing it cuts flow. Flow is the rhythmical energy of your body beyond skin. Everything about you and the universe is flow in flow. Input. Output. On repeat. Block an artery, prepare for the heart attack. Not expressing your truth kills the same way. Slow and potent. 

To be authentic is to BE in your true expression. Do not fear the BEYOUty of your authentic voice. It will always be LOVE because that is what you are when the veil comes off.

The Worrying Mind

It‚Äôs been quite the 2 weeks as we figure out what‚Äôs going on with Ganchos health. He‚Äôs now stable. Seemingly at peace as we wait for the exam results to understand more of what‚Äôs going on in his little body. Once again, as the universe does so well, she‚Äôs testing me. Luckily I‚Äôve been consistent with my practice of BEING in awareness, feeling the feels, emoting the emotions & flushing the residue of my internal happenings before they grab hold & throw me around. Not this time. Showing up is showing up for me right now.

In the past my worrying mind would‚Äôve hijacked me to the point of immobility. After years of learning how to not fear my pain, or overindulge in it, I‚Äôve found the sweet spot where all my emotions can sit at the table & have a productive cordial conversation without freaking the FUK out. In the past worry would have annihilated everyone else at the table. Now all my feelings/emotions can mingle mindfully with each other to reach a reasonable, respectable & manageable compromise for the good of every emotion that lives in my vessel.

This emotional wisdom did not come easily. I‚Äôve invested a lot of time & effort to get to where I am now in body-mind-spirit. This is crucial work. This is why we are here. To learn. To evolve. To receive the lessons & give back. Gancho is the Angel on the ground dishing out homework from the universe. I appreciate the universe‚Äôs tests and proceed onwards with gratitude for all ‚ù§Ô∏è

MovMEANT.com
Do the work. 
It‚Äôs your important work to do while here on earth.

Feelings are our friends. I know some will roll their eyes & be like ‚Äúyeah right‚Äù. Feelings can feel like the enemy but it‚Äôs only because you‚Äôre taking it personally. Have you ever tried listening & observing the feelings as a witness or vessel instead of the persona of which they are happening to? It won‚Äôt feel like an attack but an important message. Because it is. 

Imagine not having feelings. Btw, repressing feelings isn‚Äôt NOT having feelings. Repressed feelings still live in you, even louder in-fact. I‚Äôd say it‚Äôs the opposite of not having feelings. Repression/suppression amplifies the feelings, it does not rid you of them. By doing so you‚Äôre only building a stronger army inside you. 

There is no person without feelings. Those are called robots. To feel is to be alive. Feelings are essential, vital information you need to communicate with your inner & outer worlds. They help us survive, grow, adapt, connect. When you don‚Äôt allow them to speak you‚Äôre left lost in the world without your emotional GPS. The feelings only scream louder, the emotions move stronger in you. Suppress more & they‚Äôll stop nudging & start fighting. Cage them up for long enough & they‚Äôll start rotting in you. Disease. 

All they wanted was to let you know they had something important to tell you cause they care about you. If you didn‚Äôt agree at least you could have had a conversation with them instead of locking them away. Sitting & talking to your feelings is the most important conversation you‚Äôll ever have. Learn how they speak & you‚Äôll want them around more often. 

Allow me to guide you into your emotional heaven. Dm me for private sessions & more offerings.

5 of my go-to high protein snacks. Here are some quick and simple snack ideas to help you get more protein into your diet üçë

As you know, I‚Äôm a tall gal so I have to eat quite a lot of protein to help build muscle. It‚Äôs important to include a source of protein in each of your main meals but I find adding extra snacks helps get me to my target (usually aiming to hit around 150 grams of protein per day).

What are your fave high protein snacks?

1Ô∏è‚É£ Banana, Peanut Butter & Honey Rice Cakes
3 rice cakes, 1 banana, 2 tbsp peanut butter, drizzle of honey 

2Ô∏è‚É£ Turkey, Cottage Cheese & Cucumber Roll Ups

3Ô∏è‚É£ Tuna & Avo Cruskits

4Ô∏è‚É£ Boiled Eggs & Tomato

I‚Äôve been involved in sports and fitness since I was 8 years old when I began training and competing in track and field athletics.

I played so many different sports throughout my ilife, competitively and socially. I trained for sport and I trained for fitness. 

When I first stepped foot in the gym I was TERRIFIED. I had no idea what I was doing, I had no plan, no goals and no confidence to comfortably train in front of people. 

I may have had years of experience training in the field I knew (athletics) but when it came to strength training, I had no idea. I wish I had more guidance and knew what I do now to cut out years of misguided advice and following fads.

Strength training changed my life. I got introduced to it when I was at my weakest having just returned home from modelling placement. It has changed my mind, health, attitude, work ethic, confidence and career. 

Everyones fitness journey is going to look different. Different schedules, struggles, goals and motivations. I know how it feels to want to achieve something but not sure how to get there. 

Working closely with clients and helping them on their fitness journey makes me so happy, I‚Äôve decided to offer custom coaching to a limited number of clients. Intake will open March 4th and close March 22nd.

Have you ever looked back at a time in your life where you wished you had just slowed down and enjoyed it a little more? There have been many times that I wish I had been a little less preoccupied with the unnecessary nonsense that seemed to have consumed me and focused more on enjoying the present. I think back to when I was younger, I think of all the BS fad diets I tried, the stress I would put myself through to weigh less or meet some unrealistic standards for my body. I think of the things I kept wanting to change in myself and the comparisons I would make to others. 

But you know what, when I think back to those days, I don‚Äôt remember what I weighed, I don‚Äôt remember when I had visible abs or when I had a little extra padding. I remember creating memories with my family, I remember creating, travelling, meeting incredible people from all around the world and making lifelong friends. I remember all the special things that can so easily escape us on the day-to-day basis but I didn‚Äôt have a single fond memory that was associated with being restrictive or obsessive when it came to body image. 

Funnily enough the moment I decided to stop focusing on purely the aesthetic side of fitness I achieved what I wanted as a by-product of enjoying the process and getting stronger. 

If you want to start training for long term, sustainable results, check out the programs in my bio ‚ù§Ô∏è

3 Reasons your glutes aren‚Äôt going üçë

Building muscle is hard work and takes time. You have to be patient and consistent to see results. Here are some reasons you may not be seeing results and how to overcome them: 

1Ô∏è‚É£ Inadequate Training Volume or Intensity:

Issue: Building muscle requires adequate training stimulus. If you‚Äôre not training with enough intensity (upping your weights and training close to failure for at least your first compound lift) your glutes may not be receiving the necessary stimulation to grow.

Solution: Focus on increasing the intensity of your workouts by increasing the weight you‚Äôre lifting, incorporate progressive overload and include more glute-focused exercises in your routine. 

2Ô∏è‚É£ Inadequate Nutrition or Recovery:

Issue: Not fuelling your body properly and overtraining can hinder your results. 

Solution: Muscles need proper nutrition and recovery to grow. If you‚Äôre not consuming enough calories, particularly protein, your body may lack the essential building blocks for muscle growth. Additionally, inadequate rest and recovery can hinder progress. Make sure you‚Äôre getting enough quality sleep, managing stress and allowing your muscles to recover between workouts.

3Ô∏è‚É£ Not following a structured program 

Issue: Changing your workouts every session isn‚Äôt going to help you build your glutes.It can be tempting to jump on the latest glute building trend or exercise that promises to build your glutes after 1 session but the reality is that building your glutes takes time and requires you to perform the same workouts for at least 4 - 6 weeks, progressively increasing the intensity (progressive overload). 

Solution: Following a program that incorporates progressive overload and has a well structured exercise selection will help you maximise your gains. 

Ready to make some glute gains? Programs in my bio üçë

Which is your favourite venue? üòç 

So many beautiful wedding venues you can‚Äôt really go wrong. Every venue had its unique charm and it was such as wonderful day visiting some of the stunning wedding venue options in Byron Bay. 

With no locked in date or location we‚Äôre just at the start of the wedding planning extravaganza üòÇ but I‚Äôll never turn down an open day and a tasting ü•Ç

Back into a good training routine so I wanted to share a day on my plate. Things are pretty chaotic right now and I have a lot of work on so my main focus is making sure I‚Äôm fuelling my body so that I can recover well from my training and feel energised throughout the day to work and study. 

It‚Äôs important to note that each persons nutritional requirement looks different. I‚Äôm 5ft 11‚Äù and need to consume a metric shit ton (official form of measurement) of protein to help me build muscle because I am 90% limbs ü§ù

I don‚Äôt cut or bulk and I don‚Äôt restrict myself either. My whole approach to training and nutrition is making sure that it‚Äôs sustainable because it‚Äôs easy to have one good session or to stick to a diet for a day. The real win is when you can do it day after day. You see the biggest changes through consistency and it‚Äôs easy to be consistent when your approach to fitness is balanced and sustainable and most of all when you actually enjoy it. 

Anyway, I wanted to share this because I get a lot go messages about meals/what I eat so here‚Äôs a pretty standard day on my plate - hope you find some meal inspo. I bet your scrambling to the kitchen to make those tuna cruskits üòÇüòÇü§å plz don‚Äôt make them in an office environment, I will not be held responsible for you assaulting the nostrils of your coworkers

There‚Äôs not much I love more than meeting interesting people and learning what makes them tick. So when @oneplus commissioned me to interview and photograph Marc Spelmann (@iamspelmann) for @VICE, I jumped at the opportunity.

You‚Äôve probably seen Marc at work ‚Äî even if you don‚Äôt know it yet ‚Äî on Britain‚Äôs Got Talent or America‚Äôs Got Talent as his alter-ego, Magician X (@iammagicianx), leading to incredible success online and off, and hundreds of millions of fans around the world.

We spent an afternoon at Marc‚Äôs home studio in London chatting about our shared love of sci-fi, special effects, cognitive psychology, and design (among his many talents, Marc is a trained illustrator and graphic designer), and of course, magic.

Marc is, unsurprisingly, a talented wordsmith, and one thing he said keeps running circles around my head in the days since our chat, as it applies to so many human endeavours: ‚ÄúAnything is possible if you put your mind to it, and you have to have that mindset because ultimately what you‚Äôre trying to create is something that should not exist.‚Äù Brilliant.

His story is as captivating as his illusions¬†‚Äî read more from our chat at the link on my profile, and check out Marc and Magician X on Instagram and YouTube for more magic.

All photos (and video) captured on the new OnePlus 12.

More frames of HP5+ @ 800ISO (pushed 1-stop) ahead of this week‚Äôs mini-workshop and photowalk with @doyoudevelop, @leica_akademie_austria, @leica_store_vienna, and @leica_camera_classic üéûÔ∏è

Whenever I‚Äôm about to head back to Vienna, I get a happy pang similar to homesickness (appropriately, there is a word in German for exactly this: ‚Äúfernweh‚Äù); a place I was planning to call home before the pandemic (and Brexit) interrupted, I‚Äôm still aiming to make it at least a part-time home one day.

Looking back on these images from February 2020 feels a bit dreamlike¬†‚Äî news outlets were buzzing about COVID-19 during my visit. I remember being surprised that there were no border restrictions upon my return to London, as the first confirmed cases in Austria had been discovered the day of my flight.

That trip was full of promise and excitement for things to come:¬†a full Spring & Summer of travel, workshops, documentary filmmaking, and commissions; a few months in Fall set aside for apartment-hunting in Vienna; years of planning, preparing, and patience all coming to fruition.

Though the last 4 years haven‚Äôt exactly played out how I imagined (ha!), each return to Vienna feels like a mini-reset back to that pre-pandemic energy and momentum.

Hope to see some of you at Wednesday‚Äôs mini-workshop and photowalk ‚Äî¬†link in the usual places ‚úåüèº

Developed and scanned by @kirkleesphotographic üôèüèº

üîç leica vienna kodak retina ilford hp5 blackandwhite film analog photography

More views from Vienna, this time from October 2023 on the new Phoenix color film.

The last few years have been (mostly) good for analog photography: the new Leica M6, increased use of ECN-2 film stocks and processing, news of a new line of Pentax film cameras ‚Äî¬†while we‚Äôre also facing rising film prices and ongoing economic issues elsewhere, I‚Äôll take positive news when it comes.

When Phoenix was released, there was a certain amount of negativity about who was sent sample rolls as the launch coverage and reviews rolled out. The common complaint was that it was only sent to ‚Äúinfluencers‚Äù ‚Äî¬†not a term I love, though people with influence have always been a good strategy for getting the word out.

The implication was that if Phoenix had been sent to ‚Äúreal‚Äù photographers for testing, the images would have been better, or the reviews wouldn‚Äôt have been as favorable, etc. ‚Äî and that the generally-positive public feedback on the new film was only due to said influencers not wanting to get on Harman‚Äôs bad side.

This sort of commentary smells like jealousy, and I get it ‚Äî¬†there are a LOT of amazing photographers out there who haven‚Äôt been blessed by social media‚Äôs algorithmic deities, and it can be frustrating to see opportunities being handed to other people when you feel you could do better. However, indignance doesn‚Äôt do anyone any favors.

It‚Äôs also easy to be jaded, and say companies like @harmanphoto are making a money-grab by selling a limited edition product ‚Äî¬†though I‚Äôd wager most of the folks who made that argument happily took advantage of Black Friday deals.

Harman launched a new, niche product, and you can‚Äôt do that without promotion ‚Äî¬†if you can get the bulk of your press by sending people free product, more power to you.

So, let people be excited about new film! The world has enough darkness right now ‚Äî¬†choose to shine a light where you can.

(Continued in comments)

Heading back to Vienna next week ‚Äî one of my favorite cities ‚Äî to run another mini-workshop and photowalk with my buddy Jahan (@doyoudevelop) and the good folks at @leica_akademie_austria & @leica_camera_austria. Link in my bio + Stories, et al.

This time we‚Äôre digging into high-speed B&W film (3200ISO, pushing film, and the like), so I thought I‚Äôd share some images I‚Äôve been sitting on for a while.

In February 2020, I was in Vienna for a few weeks and brought along a camera I‚Äôd had in my collection for years but never used: a Kodak Retina 1a from 1953.

I slowly captured a single roll of HP5+ while wandering Vienna‚Äôs streets, zone focusing at f11‚Äì16, pushing the roll 1-stop (effectively turning 400ISO film into 800ISO) to keep the shutter speeds higher at those smaller apertures.

I‚Äôll share some more from this roll in a few days ‚Äî it‚Äôll be nice to revisit Vienna on high-speed B&W film nearly 4 years on üéûÔ∏è

Developed and scanned by @kirkleesphotographic üôèüèº

This last tip in the current smartphone photography series seems obvious once you know it: When using devices with multiple lenses, use the exact focal length (or multiplier, e.g. 2√ó, 3√ó, etc.) to Zoom with the highest quality.

Newer devices will of course give you amazing images throughout their zoom range, but just as in the days of single-lens smartphones, cropping an image slightly will provide better quality than zooming the same amount.

Thanks again to 2023 @iphotoawards partner, @oneplus, for supporting this short series of educational Reels. More tips and tricks coming your way in 2024! ‚ù§Ô∏è #open

Credits:
DP: @steveribeirodop
Production: @inkfieldmedia

White Balance (sometimes called ‚ÄúColor‚Äù or ‚ÄúTemperature‚Äù depending on your software) is a key tool when editing any image, regardless of the lighting conditions. As smart as our devices are, it‚Äôs possible for a photo to need correction if it looks different than what our eyes see ‚Äî or you may want your subject to be warmer or cooler for effect. Either way, White Balance is important to understand and use.

This is the 4th tip (of 5) in my short series with 2023 @iphotoawards partner, @oneplus. Leave a comment and let me know what sort of images you‚Äôll be capturing or editing using these tips, smartphone or otherwise! ‚ù§Ô∏è #open

DP: @steveribeirodop
Production: @inkfieldmedia

This next smartphone photography tip is all about positioning your subject when using Portrait Mode ‚Äî ensuring there is ample distance between your subject and the background helps your device determine what is in focus and what should be blurred, giving you more control over the result (and more flexibility when editing).

Edited to add: I took this picture on Christmas Day when Pope Francis made an unexpected visit to the Sistine Chapel after speaking to the people in St. Peter's Square from the balcony of the basilica. A member of the Swiss Guard paces at his post near the foot of Scala Regia, the royal staircase that connects the Apostolic Palace to St. Peter‚Äôs Basilica in Vatican City. Once a formidable mercenary force dating back 500 years, the title Swiss Guard now usually refers to the Pontifical Swiss Guard, a small force of just over 100 Swiss Catholics who serve as bodyguards to the Pope. Despite their outwardly appearance of a ceremonial role, they are a serious and well-trained combat force, equipped with modern weaponry such as submachine guns. This is an outtake from my August @natgeo magazine cover story on Pope Francis and the Vatican. A National Geographic book from the assignment will also be published on August 4. #swissguard #vatican #thephotosociety

The largest-ever astronomical project, ALMA, is a cooperation between the three continents--North America, Europe, and East Asia--to build and network 66 radio antennas at 16,500 feet altitude in the Atacama Desert in Chile. The radio telescope array is searching the heavens for clues about the origins of the Universe and many other mysteries. This picture was shot on assignment for National Geographic Magazine, for a story that will be running in the April issue. #atacama #chile #ALMA @thephotosociety

Thinking of the late Dr. Eugenie Clark on shark awareness day. Genie, also known as the shark lady that spent her life studying shark behavior as a Professor at the University of Maryland and @motemarinelab . I was fortunate to document and learn from her research for three decades at National Geographic . Her studies are the foundation for scientists who follow in her wake dispelling the myths and mysteries about these creatures that should be celebrated and protected, not feared. #SharkAwarenessDay #Sharks #TheSharkLady #MoreOcean with @daviddoubilet

Hey! I just learned it is World Sea Turtle Day and there is nothing like meeting these incredible ancient mariners in the sea. This endangered green sea turtle hatchling swims into its future in the open sea off Nengonengo Atoll, French Polynesia. This little one could live 70+  years if it survives the many challenges it will face from natural predation, habitat loss, entanglement and illegal harvest #HappyWorldSeaTurtleDay #SeaTurtle #Hope #MoreOcean with @daviddoubilet

I want to share good news on World Oceans Day: our current @natgeo story RESHARK -A WILD PLAN to put zebra sharks from aquariums back into the sea appears in the July issue. In this frame Marine scientist @neshaichida gently swims a juvenile zebra shark through its nursery sea pen habitat  at  @rarcc (Raja Ampat Research Conservation Center) located at @papuadivingresorts on Kri island in Indonesia. A team of biologists affectionately known as shark Nannie‚Äôs will conduct a final health assessment before the shark is transported for release into Wayag Islands a patrolled Marine Protected Area where historic populations of zebra sharks were fished out. This global collaboration of  70+ stakeholders from 15 countries (and growing)  is the first of kind to Rewild sharks from 44 participating aquariums. And the best news: This is just the beginning - @reshark_org does not stop at Zebra Sharks. #WorldOceanDay #Sharks #babyshark #Reshark #moreocean with @jenniferhayesig and @daviddoubilet

Backstage microphone check before Nat Geo Live at @vancivictheatres in May with @jenniferhayesig. Shout out and  big THANK YOU to all of our colleagues on the NG Live team (from its beginning to now) for helping us take our  @natgeo stories to the stage. The speaker series is a chance to connect one on one with emerging story tellers, scientists and explorers  and hopefully inspire them to follow their passions what ever they may be. You make a difference. #NGLive #Gratitude #WhatIsYourNature

Great to be in La Jolla - The Village By The Sea-  for NG Live tonight (May 25) at @ljmusicsociety.  A harp seal pup waits for it mother to return in the Gulf of St. Lawrence ice nursery near Magdalen Island . This is who we share our planet with. It is our to protect or lose. #NGLive #WhatIsYourNature with @jenniferhayesig

You are invited to Folsom Lake College May 11 for National Geographic Live at @harriscenter. Penguins rest on ice  in Antarctica. The small group was wary that I was a leopard seal on the prowl and they were on the menu. When a brave gentoo leaped and swam around me the others gained confidence and followed. #NGLive #WhatIsYourNature #MoreOcean with @jenniferhayesig

Looking forward to VANCOUVER May 9 at @vancivictheatres . Join us for an evening of National Geographic Live: the stories behind the NG story.  Papua New Guinea: plunging to seamounts searching for coral; Descend into Cubas Gardens  of the Queen, a Caribbean museum and explore life in the ice with a herd of 10000 harp seals.  #NatGeoLive #MoreOcean @jenniferhayesig  #WhatIsYourNature

Countdown Jan 26 BURLINGTON / TORONTO Ontario. Join us for National Geographic Live At the @burlington_pac  for the stories behind the @natgeo story. Come on assignment in remote Papua New Guinea and explore  beneath the polar ice, a universe of pinnipeds and penguins making their living in the world of water light and ice.  #OceansThroughTheLensOfTime #CoralKingdomsEmpiresOfIIce

Count down to Nov 16 Mesa AZ Join us for National Geographic Live At the @mesaartscenter  for the stories behind the @natgeo story: We will explore life beneath the polar ice and submerge into Cuba‚Äôs Gardens of the Queen, a living Caribbean museum  with teeming coral reefs and dense mangroves patrolled by curious American crocodiles that appear briefly to watch us work and then leave to do other crocodile things. . Assignments are filled with life changing encounters with wildlife that keeps my partner  @jenniferhayesig and I returning each year to tell their story. #OceansThroughTheLensOfTime #CoralKingdomsEmpiresOfIceg #NGLive #JenniferAndHerCrocodile

Tonight 23 Sept LA /  Thousand Oaks Join us for National Geographic Live At the Bank Of America Performing Arts Center for the stories behind the @natgeo story: plunge into Papua New Guinea richest reefs  and submerge into iceberg gardens to meet life in the ice.  Assignments are predictably unpredictable ‚Ä¶  there are magic encounters, monsoons, malaria and life changing encounters with wildlife that keeps @jenniferhayesig and I coming back to tell their story #OceansThroughTheLensOfTime #CoralKingdomsEmpiresOfIce #nglivelements

Healthy Made Simple is out today! Changing my diet changed my life, it gave me my health back and ever since my mission has been to help more people to eat more plants more of the time. 

Healthy living should be joyful, colourful, abundant, flavoursome, and delicious üí´üå± It should also be easy, so that you can eat well all the time. So, every recipe has five promises:

1. It‚Äôll take 30 minutes or less.¬†
2. It‚Äôll contain fewer than 10 ingredients 
3. It‚Äôll have no more than 5 steps.‚Ä®4. It‚Äôll be healthy and packed with goodness.¬†
5. It‚Äôll be delicious

I‚Äôm so proud of this book and truly feel like the luckiest person in the world to have a platform that can make a difference to other peoples lives. Thank you for letting me do what I do and I really hope the ease and simplicity this book brings to your life makes all the difference üíû

It‚Äôs in all book shops and Amazon now üëèüèª Please let me know if yours has arrived!

Just a little reminder that when you find a lifestyle that‚Äôs sustainable, that‚Äôs wellness. When looking after your mind and body feels balanced, celebratory, delicious and full of abundance and colour, that‚Äôs wellness üíû It‚Äôs not all or nothing, it‚Äôs not a life of deprivation; it‚Äôs nourishment, self-compassion and remembering that it‚Äôs what you do for decades, not on any given day, that matters‚ú®
