Packed with plant protein, these sticky miso tofu bowls with peas, edamame and ginger are nourishing, flavoursome and super easy to make. Thanks @deliciouslyella. 

Ingredients¬†
2 servings of basmati rice, (about 100g / 3.5 oz) rinsed¬†
1 tablespoon olive oil¬†
Small chunk of ginger, (about 20g / 0.7 oz) cut into matchsticks/grated¬†
2 large cloves garlic, thinly sliced¬†
1 tablespoon tamari¬†
100g / ¬æ cup / 3.5 oz frozen peas, defrosted¬†
100g / ¬æ cup / 3.5 oz frozen edamame beans, defrosted¬†
Pinch of sea salt 

For the sticky tofu¬†
1 tablespoon olive oil¬†
1 block firm smoked tofu, (about 280g / 10 oz) drained & cut into bite-sized pieces¬†
1 tablespoon tamari¬†
2 tablespoons maple syrup¬†
2 tablespoons brown rice miso paste¬†
2 tablespoons rice wine vinegar 

Method¬† 

Pour the rice into a small saucepan, along with 200ml / 7 fl oz water and a large pinch of salt. Bring to the boil, then cover with a lid, reduce the heat to low and simmer for 10 minutes until all of the water has been absorbed. Remove from the heat and set aside.¬†
¬†
While the rice is cooking, warm 1 tablespoon of oil in a large frying pan set over medium‚Äìhigh heat. Add the tofu and cook for 10 minutes, stirring often, until crisp and golden on all sides.¬†
¬†
Next, whisk together 1 tablespoon tamari, the maple syrup, miso paste and rice wine vinegar. Once the tofu is cooked, pour the sauce into the pan and let it reduce to create a sticky sauce that coats the tofu. Remove the tofu from the pan and set aside on a plate.¬†
¬†
Pour 1 tablespoon of olive oil into the same pan, followed by the cooked rice, ginger and garlic. Fry for 5 minutes, until crisp, then stir in the tamari, peas, edamame beans and crispy tofu. Divide between 2 bowls and serve with your favourite crispy chilli oil/sauce.

I‚Äôm making this on repeat at the moment, so wanted to share the recipe with you. It‚Äôs a family favourite, such a good staple and one of the easiest ways to up your veggie intake. It‚Äôs a nice one for food waste too, simply swap the veg for anything you‚Äôve got lying around at home - leeks, whole tomatoes, courgettes, leafy greens etc are all delicious additions, likewise white beans instead of chickpeas and any pasta shape instead of orecchiette (broken pieces of lasagne are fab, as is orzo). Dial the chilli up or down to taste, or simply add it at the end if you‚Äôre making this for little ones (once you‚Äôve served them) 

For the nourishing veggie broth with orecchiette, you‚Äôll need 
- 2 tablespoons olive oil
- 1 large onion, thinly sliced
- 2 carrots, halved lengthways & cut into 1cm half moons
- 2 sticks of celery, finely chopped
- 4 cloves garlic, crushed/finely chopped
- 2 bay leaves
- small handful of thyme sprigs
- 1 tablespoon tomato pur√©e
- 1 tablespoon brown rice miso paste
- 1 x 400g tin chopped tomatoes
- 1 x 400g tin chickpeas, drained
- 1¬º litre vegetable stock
- 3 servings of orecchiette (about 225g)
- large handful of basil
- pinch of dried red chilli flakes
- pinch of sea salt

1. Warm the olive oil in a large deep saucepan or casserole dish set over medium heat. Add the onion, carrots, celery, garlic, a pinch of salt and cook for 5 minutes until slightly softened.

2. Stir in the bay leaves, thyme leaves, tomato pur√©e and miso; cook for 2‚Äì3 minutes until fragrant. 

3. Next, pour in the tinned tomatoes, chickpeas and stock. Bring to the boil, then reduce the heat and simmer for 10‚Äì15 minutes until the vegetables are tender. 

4. Remove the pan from the heat and use a hand blender to roughly blitz half of the soup to thicken it slightly (if you like), then return to the heat, add the pasta and cook for 8‚Äì10 minutes until al dente. 

5. Divide between bowls and scatter over the basil, chilli flakes (if using) and a drizzle of olive oil

The recipe is from our website/app alongside 1,000+ other delicious, plant-based recipes: https://www.deliciouslyella.com/recipes/nourishing-veggie-broth-with-orecchiette/

Ukraine March 2024

(Kim Gordon on repeat. Her newest music, made at age 70) üî•
Even away from the trenches, everyday life is a terrifying, hard, heartbreaking struggle for Ukrainians. Feb. 2024
Ukraine, February 2024

‚ÄúHi Anna. Our brigade surrenders in captivity today. Me too. I don‚Äôt know what will happen next. I love you all.‚Äù
_____________

Waiting for Serhiy

His attempts to escape the Russian siege had failed. He and his fellow Ukrainian Marines were surrounded, dozens of miles from friendly lines. They were nearly out of food and ammunition. Some panicked, others quietly resigned themselves to what would come next.
Then, a few days later, senior sailor Sergey Hrebinyk and his comrades emerged from the sprawling Ilyich Iron and Steel works in the southern Ukrainian city of Mariupol. He quickly messaged his older sister: ‚ÄúHi Anna. Our brigade surrenders. In captivity today. I also don‚Äôt know what will happen next. I love you.‚Äù
It was April 12, 2022.

Nearly two years later, on the second anniversary of the start of Russia‚Äôs full scale invasion, Serhiy Hrebinyk, 24, remains in captivity as a prisoner of war, held somewhere in Russia. His family sits in purgatory, trapped between that day in April and the present.

The initial panicked flurry of calls to the Red Cross, the Ukrainian military and local officials subsided as official proof of life took months to come. The war dragged on, and now, like thousands of other Ukrainian families with relatives in captivity, the Hrebinyks wait.

‚ÄúLife, of course, has changed. Almost every day is filled with tears,‚Äù said Svitlana Hrebinyk, Serhiy‚Äôs mother.

Words @tmgneff Photos @dguttenfelder Editing @adamjdean for @nytimes in Sumy. Ukraine marking two years of war since the full-scale Russian invasion.

Ukrainian soldiers rested inside a destroyed building on the edge of the newly liberated but desolate village of Blahodatne. It was one of seven villages that Ukraine had retaken during the early days of the counteroffensive against Russia and just one of dozens, or hundreds that would need to be bled over if their strategy could succeed. 

This photograph is part of the @nytimes 2023 The Year In Pictures. It‚Äôs been a year of very dark days and unprecedented danger for fellow journalists in Gaza and Lebanon, Israel, Ukraine... 

Please have a look at the pictures (link in my bio) and read the words of some of the women and men who stood their ground with their cameras.

Ukrainian military manning tanks and mobile artillery (and a ‚ÄúBuhanka‚Äù) on the Kharkiv front lines.
December 2023

Everything that rises must converge.

Kyiv 11/27/23

Ukraine October 2023

Emerging from an underground bunker in a tree line, Ukrainian soldiers fired their 50+ year old Soviet-era artillery at Russian frontline infantry near Bakhmut. 

The town cleared another acre of ground and began digging fresh graves to make room for many of the 52 killed in one vicious Russian missile strike on mourners who‚Äôd gathered for a wake in the village of Hroza. 

A steady flow of injured soldiers, cared for by combat medics in this hidden Donetsk region outpost. 

Boots and bloody clothing, cut away from injured Ukrainian soldiers before evacuation from the front, were heaped in the hallway and yard at one combat medic outpost in the Kupiansk direction. 

@nytimes

Yuri, a Ukrainian villager from Hroza, wandered in the ruins. His wife Halyna died here the day before. 

A missile strike on the Ukrainian village of Hroza killed at least 52 people, including every known member of one family in the area. As much as a third of the population were killed in the attack. 

‚ÄúEverybody died,‚Äù one resident said.

After completing our trek in the Annapurna Range, we decided to fly over our trekking route to grasp the distance we traveled on foot.
Camp 2, Ama Dablam. Words can‚Äôt describe this cold and windswept campsite at 6040m...

What powers your dreams? 
For me it‚Äôs utter simplicity. The freedom a car gives, and to have all your possessions in one backpack. This enables me to be nimble and pursue life changing experiences. For example, witnessing the awe of the midnight sun in the pristine landscape of Lofoten, Norway. 
I am excited to announce that I‚Äôll be teaming up with @HondaEurope¬†for the Milan Design Week, where a new power of dreams will be revealed. Stay tuned!

This weekend I‚Äôll do a takeover for @faracycling. It‚Äôs an honour to represent this boutique Norwegian bicycle brand. Follow the journey on my FARA Gravel R, and feel free to ask any questions!

#AD This Easter I spent visiting my favourite fjord, enjoying the unpredictable weather in @Columbia_eu ‚Äòs OutDry and Omni-Tech clothes. Even though it snowed, rained and was sunny at the same time, the shoes and the jacket kept me happy.
This summer I am definitely returning for more hikes and climbs! #MadeForOutside
New year's day with good company and a swim.
I spent the entire month of July cycling, hiking and camping along the coast of Norway. At the end of my sojourn @upnorth_outdoors_norway took me up Norway‚Äôs Ama Dablam, Stetinden!
@VGnett made a video reportage of my favourite hike in Norway. Link in bio!

Within a week I‚Äôll begin my second bicycle-tour of Norway, but first I took my family to one of my favourite hikes in our county. Even my sister‚Äôs little dog joined us for the gruelling 21km hike with an elevation gain exceeding 1300m. At the summit someone had left homemade cloudberry liqueur. To whom ever made the liqueur it was delicious!

An empty Pulpit in June is impressive, but nothing compared to the 19-year-old adventurous Dutchie we met on the rock @guus_malenstein. His original plan was to cycle from the Netherlands to Trondheim (Norway), but the moment he arrived in Denmark his bike disintegrated. Without sufficient funds to make the repairs he decided to walk instead. At the Norwegain border he told the border guards that he needed to visit his grandmother. The guards let him in.‚Å£
‚Å£
I must admit, I‚Äôm impressed by the young crazy Dutchie. You don‚Äôt meet brave people like him daily, who are on a thousand-kilometre trek alone admits a pandemic. ‚Å£
‚Å£
üé• @andreassolbakken

The moment my sister and I left for Rio de Janeiro the first case of covid-19 was confirmed in Norway. A week after arriving back home the entire world had shut down, I cannot believe our luck! I hope everyone is keeping strong during these unprecedented times. ‚Å£
‚Å£
After completing my exams, I finally got around to share this set which contains my sister and I being tourists doing touristy things‚Å£. #DigernesTheTourist

‚ÄúIn the rest of the world, so many different forms of celebrity do exist. Let's just say things are changing. And I think we're here to stay,‚Äù says #Vogue India‚Äôs #October digital cover star Diipa B√ºller-Khosla (@diipakhosla). Read the full interview at the link in bio.

Grateful & honoured for the invitation to join the the 33rd Women in Business conference of THE Harvard Business School!!! @hbswomen @harvardhbs 

As any Indian girl my parents would have loved for me to attend Harvard, but life turned out differently‚Ä¶

Little did I know my baby @indewild would take me to speak at Harvard Business School to 900+ students of the MBA class.ü•π‚ô•Ô∏è

It‚Äôs officially ‚ù§Ô∏è month and I was blessed to support the @american_heart association on its mission to bring more awareness to prevention, CPR education, and patients battling heart disease! 

From ringing the @nyse opening bell to teaching a live world-wide CPR course to supporting the wear red for women event, I can say this has been a week for the books! #nationoflifesavers #heartmonth #aha
The brutal & sad reality many patients face! Even my angel of a nurse who‚Äôs given nearly 50 years to healthcare ‚òπÔ∏è

I am really excited to announce my partnership with @biodermausa for 2024! You may remember that they were kind enough to donate $500k of skincare products to my healthcare colleagues during the pandemic and they loved them. One of the leading brands in dermatological skincare, BIODERMA is devoted to supporting medical professionals and consumers alike.

Since then, I have been a fan of many of their products, and now I‚Äôm excited to highlight them. Starting off this dry, irritating winter season is their Atoderm Shower Oil & Atoderm Intensive Balm.

Because my skin gets really flaky and itchy during the dry winter months, I‚Äôve been using The Atoderm Shower Oil as a cleanser to help restore optimal hydration right from the shower. Then, post-shower, I follow up with The Atoderm Intensive Balm to lock in moisture to reduce dryness and irritation for the rest of the day. #biodermapartner #strongetogether

Super excited to share that my new book Even More Basics to Brilliance is on sale today! 
This book follows my favourite format - showing you all the tips, tricks and shortcuts to master a basic recipe followed by the simple switch-up to make one basic recipe even more brilliant! 
Some of my faves include my highly addictive crispy chilli oil, Asian beef short ribs, the most comforting mac and cheese plus the sweetness you need to add to your life - lemon drizzle cake, cinnamon scrolls and the silkiest chocolate mousse. I absolutely loved putting this book together so I hope you love it as much as I do. Tap the link in bio to shop. Happy Cooking! D.x

#cookbook

I‚Äôm now adding a little touch of sweetness to your day. 
 
My new range of small-batch, made-from-scratch, crisp-edged, fudgy-centred cookies are now baking! Some of you have been lovingly buying my books for many years, so I thought it was my turn to treat you with a made-with-love morsel of deliciousness - made using only the best ingredients. We are starting small and delivering in a limited area via Uber Eats. 
 
Choose from single flavours, the Classics Mixed Box filled with all the crowd-pleasers, or the special guest stars ‚Äì a mixed box of limited edition flavours. This week‚Äôs limited edition flavour is raspberry white chocolate. Enjoy! Tap the link in bio to view and shop what‚Äôs baking today. D.x

Our end of Summer SALE starts now!
We are sad to see the official end of summer so we are giving you 30% off storewide* Discount applied at checkout. *Excludes baking mixes, grouped products, books with bonus gifts, hampers and gift vouchers. Online sale ends 11.59pm AEST, Sunday 3 March 2024. Happy shopping! D.x

The gentle cooking of steam, combined with the heat of convection is the secret to this perfectly cooked one pan wonder, Pistachio Crusted Salmon on Herbed Potatoes. Create potatoes with crispy edges and a soft, fluffy centre, ready to be topped with a warm and zesty herb dressing. My herb, lemon and pistachio crust for the salmon adds a delicate balance of flavour and crunch. The amazing combination of steam with convection using the Miele Combi steam oven, allows you to cook soft delicate salmon with a golden crust. This perfectly cooked one pan dish has all the flavours and textures you will love. Clever combination cooking perfection! Find the recipe on my website or at the link in bio. D.x

I get asked all the time whether or not I bait my camera traps. My answer is that if you can find a place that the animal wants to go naturally, you‚Äôre way better off than trying to convince a wild animal to go somewhere you want it to you. In this instance, if you can find where they want to sleep you know you‚Äôre onto something good.

I caught these two young bull moose going head to head on one of the camera traps we had set up in @isleroyalenps.  This pretty much sums up the new techniques I‚Äôve been using in my camera traps lately. Autofocus üò¨. No lights üò≥. Silent cameras üòé. It‚Äôs pretty tough going, but when it works, man it works.  I also think it‚Äôs a lot more likely to generate images capturing better behavior as there are no sounds or lights to disturb the animals while they‚Äôre doing their thing. What do you think?

Which Chef put together the more delicious looking Super Bowl Wings Inspired Spread? Team Drums led by Chef @monwahbs or Team Flats led by Chef @howardseivright ?

We all know that no event celebrates the spirit of competition like the Super Bowl. And we all know that food is a major part of that event. 

But did you know that there is a an even fiercer competition that has been going on between food lovers even before the first Super Bowl was played?

This battle is the battle for wing supremacy. Drums or Flats. The debate over which is the better bite is more intense than any football fans love for their favorite team and their despising of their rivals. 

So I got some @pintysfoods wings and two of my favourite chefs to battle it out by making the most appetizing Super Bowl spreads possible. 

We had a drafts, wing related trivia, and a lot of food and a lot of fun. Check it out!!!

I‚Äôm headed to Berlin in May to teach a workshop with @eyesinprogress focused on visual storytelling.‚Å£
‚Å£
Participants will take their documentary reportage skills to the next level by covering a story through photography. We will go over how to refine your storytelling and story composition by analyzing real-situation problems, images analysis, editing and captions writing.‚Å£
‚Å£
Most of all, this workshop will help you discover your own visual language as well as practical and conceptual know-how to confront real situations and build compelling narratives through your photographs.‚Å£
‚Å£
Head to the link in my bio to sign up!‚Å£
‚Å£
@viifoundation @reduxpictures #viiphoto #edkashi #berlin #photoworkshops #eyesinprogress #photoworkshops

In this immersive five-day workshop in Santa Fe with Ed Kashi, the primary emphasis is guiding participants in creating and finalizing a personal project. Students also have the opportunity to complete individual assignments on-location and practice their skills related to research, scouting, shooting within a deadline, and delivering a final product. These projects serve as the cornerstone defining our identity as visual storytellers and artists. Echoing Ed‚Äôs approach, the ultimate goal is to identify subjects that ignite a profound passion and document them using a unique and impactful visual style. 

Drawing from his extensive repertoire, Ed showcases his varied personal projects, collaborations with NGOs and Foundations, and editorial contributions to acclaimed publications such as National Geographic, Time, and The New Yorker. 

Together, we examine diverse visual formats like photographs, multimedia, and short films, exploring the vibrant array of creative possibilities. Engage in an intimate and safe environment to present your work, exploring innovative methods of visual storytelling using available mediums like photography, text, and motion. Conceptual approaches are welcomed. Receive both individual and group critiques on your workshop creations, while also having the chance to seek feedback on other ongoing projects.

I am pleased to announce a new exhibition of photographs from my newest book, Abandoned Moments, at the @mammontclair. The exhibition will be up March 22 - May 19 in Montclair, New Jersey. In contrast to the documentary and journalistic approaches that characterize most of my photography, my ‚Äúabandoned moments‚Äù work instead relies on intuition and my gut in order to capture images without looking through the viewfinder. Photographs from my personal project documenting Syrian refugee camps in Jordan and Iraq. After having worked in Syria over 7 trips between 1991 and 2009, once their brutal civil war exploded out of the Arab Spring, I was determined to find a way to tell the story of mental health amongst Syrian refugees. This was a story that was dear to me and I had the chance to pitch the idea to International Medical Corps. I spent two weeks in Northern Iraq and Jordan to tell this story, which was ultimately published by Time magazine.‚Å£
Throughout my career personal projects have defined my work and been the lifeblood of my working life.‚Å£
‚Å£
I head to beautiful New Mexico in July to teach a workshop with @santafeworkshops. In this immersive five-day workshop, the primary emphasis is guiding participants in creating and finalizing a personal project.‚Å£
‚Å£
These projects serve as the cornerstone of our identity as visual storytellers and artists. Students will have the opportunity to complete individual assignments on-location and practice their skills related to research, scouting, shooting within a deadline, and delivering a final product.‚Å£

Mirror, Mirror | ‚ÄúMirror, Mirror, on the wall, who‚Äôs the fairest of them all?‚Äù This now ubiquitous English phrase came from a Disney movie, Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs.‚Å£
‚Å£
In photography, mirrors play an important role, serving as a compositional device, and as an element that makes the image more magical, dramatic, mysterious or just visually engaging. The creative use of mirrors in photography gives a poetic license to create imagery that is less obvious or straightforward, but allows for alternative ways of capturing a moment, a character and a scene. It can also be an effective way of avoiding direct contact with a subject or to render a sensitive or difficult situation without direct confrontation.‚Å£
‚Å£
These images from my archive reflect the multitude of ways mirrors serve as visual devices in photography.‚Å£
‚Å£
Captions:‚Å£
‚Å£
1. Donia Remedios, 73, who has pancreatic cancer, spends time at home with her daughter, Orlanda Hernandez Ramirez Remedios, 44, at their family compound. MEXICO 2014‚Å£
‚Å£
2. A Muslim woman is reflected in a car mirror while Christian women are seen walking down the street in Kano. NIGERIA 2013‚Å£
‚Å£
3. Backstage at the Al Fala Theatre in Lahore, actress Nida Chaudrey reflection speaks of the bawdy and racy burlesque shows for which the theater is known. Bombed in early 2009 by extremists attempting to send a message, patrons still attend regularly. The sexual entertainment attracts mostly male viewers who pack the evening shows, but occasionally couples and families also attend. PAKISTAN 2009‚Å£
‚Å£
4. Wealthy young Kuwaitis shop for jewelry at Bulgari. KUWAIT 2000‚Å£
‚Å£
5. Clouds drift in the sky over Bozeman, Montana. USA 2015‚Å£

The City of the Dead: 30 Years Back | Photography Exhibition By Ed Kashi @edkashi
‚Äé  ŸÖÿØŸäŸÜÿ© ÿßŸÑŸÖŸàÿ™Ÿâ : ŸÖÿß ŸÇÿ®ŸÑ Ÿ£Ÿ† ÿπÿßŸÖ | ŸÖÿπÿ±ÿ∂ ÿ™ÿµŸàŸäÿ± ŸÅŸàÿ™Ÿàÿ∫ÿ±ÿßŸÅŸä ŸÑŸÑŸÖÿµŸàÿ± ÿßŸäÿØ ŸÉÿßÿ¥Ÿä

After the loss of some of our heritage buildings due to the latest city of the dead demolitions, this exhibition depicts the timeless historic area as photographed in 1993 by celebrated photographer Ed Kashi.  You are invited to one of the oldest cemeteries in the world, as curated by Photopia as an immersive experience for the viewers to contemplate and enjoy.

Opening night: 23 February, 2024 &  lasts till 2 March , 2024 
Working hours: 12 pm- 9 pm 
Location: Citadel Cairo 

The oldest continuously used Muslim Cemetery in the world, the City of the Dead, with history tracing back to the seventh century. Cairo‚Äôs vast 13th century cemetery, the only living occupants, were caretakers paid by families to maintain their ancestral mausoleums.
In 1993, over one hundred and twenty thousand people lived, worked, shopped, and went to school in and among the mausoleums. Today, that number is much higher, huts are built around tombstones, between which laundry is hung to dry, and masses of people live and work in dwellings built amongst the grand burial sites of famous religious and political figures of Egypt‚Äôs rich history. This exhibition pays tribute to the historic area, its people & their stories.
This exhibition is sponsored by the US embassy in Cairo.

Visual Riffs: Coupling | What does it mean to couple? The dictionary frames it as ‚Äúthe act of bringing or coming together.‚Äù ‚Å£
‚Å£
From the romantic to the traumatic, how do two people hold together and why or what brings them together. In some sense it‚Äôs the most desired and natural relationship humans strive to attain, yet two people can be brought together for reasons or circumstances that are not positive or romantic or comforting. This carousel explores the various forms of coupling I‚Äôve documented over the years around the world.‚Å£
‚Å£
Captions:‚Å£
‚Å£
1. A woman visits her partner in prison. USA 1987‚Å£
‚Å£
2. A woman and man make out in Daytona Beach, a popular party destination. USA 2001‚Å£
‚Å£
3. Corey Terry with his girlfriend, Lakia Oliver, 25, at his house in Baltimore. Terry, 20, was a heroin dealer in East Baltimore until he went to prison as a youth. He is now out of prison and turning his life around with the help of Hand To Hand. USA 2011‚Å£
‚Å£
4. Marines from Lima Company celebrate the 230th birthday of the United States Marine Corps at their annual Marine Ball, which took place at the Renaissance Hotel in Columbus, Ohio. They recently returned from a tour in Iraq. USA 2005‚Å£
‚Å£
5. A couple enjoys the end of the day with calm beauty in Yangon. BURMA 2012‚Å£
‚Å£
6. A couple walks on a path in a nudist section of the Danube National Wetlands Park. AUSTRIA 2001‚Å£

A recent article in The Economist reported on the issue of stray cows in India and how the right‚Äôs pro-cow policies are doing little to protect the sacred animals. I‚Äôve traveled to India over 10 times on assignment and have seen with my own eyes the way cows are a part of daily life. I‚Äôve always been fascinated by the special position cows have in Hindu society. At first I thought it was unusual, but over the years and many visits I‚Äôve come to not only appreciate the beliefs around a cow‚Äôs sacredness, but also understand that virtually every part of a cow, from their feces, meat, bones, skin, urine, etc, has a value. Whether it‚Äôs using their feces for fuel or building your home, to their skin for clothing and protection, it‚Äôs incredible what overall value, at least from a human‚Äôs perspective of dominion over the natural world, represents. No wonder cows are considered sacred. ‚Å£
‚Å£
But I‚Äôve also seen the downside of this reverence, where cows are left to wander and get sick and literally die on the streets. The ruling conservative party, BJP, has passed several ‚Äúpro-cow‚Äù policies like a ban on cow slaughter, but that has only led to the proliferation of stray cows, now numbering over 5 million. 

Abandoned, they often feed on plastic bags and other garbage, and can cause car crashes and destroy crops. One thing is certain ‚Äì the current situation is untenable and more must be done to protect India‚Äôs stray cows.‚Å£
‚Å£

Visual Riff: Coupling | What does it mean to couple? The dictionary frames it as ‚Äúthe act of bringing or coming together.‚Äù ‚Å£
‚Å£
From the romantic to the traumatic, how do two people hold together and why or what brings them together. In some sense, it‚Äôs the most desired and natural relationship humans strive to attain, yet two people can be brought together for reasons or circumstances that are not positive or romantic or comforting.
‚Å£
There have been couples I‚Äôve met in my lifetime, and I imagine anyone reading this has experienced the same thing, who are so perfectly matched, that if they were to ever break up you‚Äôd think the world was coming to an end. The qualities that I see exemplifying coupling are trust, care, being able to listen and make space for a mate‚Äôs feelings and thoughts, and of course being able to laugh with each other. Yet, some people couple out of desperation, need, economics, lust and social pressures.‚Å£

Captions:‚Å£
‚Å£
1. A wife brushes her husband‚Äôs hair. He has been transferred to the assisted living section of the residence, which overlooks the children‚Äôs playground. USA 1997‚Å£
‚Å£
2. Two women embrace at the Oranien Bar, or ‚ÄúO-Bar‚Äù as it is known on Berlin‚Äôs West side. It is a meeting place for gays, lesbians, straights or any combination of the above. GERMANY 1991‚Å£
‚Å£
3. New mother Wendy, 36, and her lesbian partner Lori, 46, enjoy their first moments with their newborn son Joshua. USA 2004‚Å£
‚Å£
4. Sunbathers on Florida‚Äôs Deerfield Beach. USA 2000‚Å£
‚Å£
5. Two residents of the Robertson Street Project enjoy a tender moment in one of their apartments. They have both come to this residence after living on the streets. Housing solutions for the elderly illustrate the extremes of British society. UK 1998‚Å£

The hotel in the Cotswolds that has it all: incredibly beautiful design, delicious food, a spa with an outdoor and indoor swimming pool, a cocktail bar, a games room and friendly service - let me introduce you to @cowleymanor [press stay]. My first experience of @experimentalgroup hotels and hopefully not the last! We opted for lunch instead of dinner and enjoyed an excellent Sunday roast. Taking inspiration from each chapter of Cowley Manor‚Äôs book, spanning from 1695 until today, designer Doroth√©e Meilichzon has carefully woven together classical inspiration with contemporary elements - from baldaquin beds to bold colour patterns and use of rattan - I loved all the details! I used a recent opportunity to take some photos inside Westminster Abbey, and while it‚Äôs a very popular tourist destination I managed to get a couple of shots when it wasn‚Äôt too crowded. 
Since 1066, it has been the location of the coronations of 40 English and British monarchs, and at least 16 royal weddings have taken place at the abbey since 1100.

#visitlondon #tlpicks #iamatraveler #prettycitylondon #thisislondon

Starting from today if you‚Äôre visiting Westminster Abbey, you can also explore the story of the French gothic masterpiece, Notre Dame de Paris from its earliest origins in the 12th century and its 850-year history to its restoration following the devastating fire of 2019 in this immersive, interactive exhibition. Open until the 1st June at Capter House @westminsterabbeylondon, the exhibition is included in the Westminster Abbey admission price but you need to book a time slot. 

#visitlondon #prettycitylondon #tlpicks #iamatraveler #thisislondon

New restaurant to try in Borough Yards - @akara.london, named after the popular West African street food dish, Akara offers a variety of crispy savoury fritters made from black eye beans, served with different fillings - we tried BBQ tiger prawn and Braised ox cheek [invite]. Don‚Äôt miss the Rice Pancakes with Black-eyed Bean Hummus and Efik Style Coconut rice. For mains, there‚Äôs a selection of barbecued meat, fish and vegetable plates. Dark Chocolate, Kahluah and Citrus Meringue Dessert was very light and perfect to finish this delicious meal.

‚ÄúLight Walker‚Äù

A self portrait series from just a few weeks ago in Deadvlei, Namibia.  A place I‚Äôve dreamed of visiting for a decade‚Ä¶ and yet being there in person, walking barefoot across the dead marsh under these 600-900 year old skeleton trees, was such a surreal experience unlike what I imagined it would be.  It‚Äôs strange to walk through a place that feels so long dead and forgotten - yet still full of life and wonder.

I originally had an entirely different series of images in my mind for here, involving a couple of different colourful dresses (red and gold) and dance poses mimicking and flowing with these trees‚Ä¶ but when I arrived here, just as the sun rose and lit up my surroundings and as I walked over the last sand dune to see the dead pan valley floor below, all those earlier visions I had simply vanished. Thankfully, tucked away in the bottom of my backpack under my camera gear and red/gold dresses (anyone else cram dresses and chocolate into their backpack as a general hiking norm?), I had also this white dress as a back-up‚Ä¶ and I was so glad I brought it, because all I could actually envision in person here was a balance of death and life, light and dark, a dream walking through decay. 

And so that‚Äôs how I spent the next 3 hours - walking and running around barefoot, feeling connection, contrast and awe, and creating this new series as it came to me. ü§ç What a surreal place.

‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî

P.S. For those wondering, this dress was made by the lovely @kayame.wear ü•∞

‚ÄúThe Heart of Ancient Earth‚Äù

3/100 of my year-long self portrait project. üíô

This was taken at 2am in Iceland - the only time I‚Äôve ever seen this location, Reynisfjara beach, completely empty of visitors.  The basalt columns eerily rose out of the midsummer night fog, and everything was still and silent, even the waves in the ocean right next to these columns - a calm rarity I‚Äôve never seen here before. 

This was my first night ever being high enough in the north to experience no complete darkness, even at 2am.  The light was soft and blue, and the settings and emotions felt in this place all came together to inspire this self portrait‚Ä¶ a moment of connection with the ancient earth. üíô

‚ÄúArise‚Äù

I‚Äôm feeling very ready for a gentle, soft and slow December. This month I want to let my mind rest, let my body feel at ease, and my heart feel opened. After a very busy travel and work season for the last few months, I‚Äôm so excited to take December to slow down and let myself become in tune with my natural surroundings, especially as winter sets in‚Ä¶ letting myself slow down and rest, just like the trees, the animals and the mountains as they become blanketed in snow for this new cozy season. üíï

This image here holds the exact kind of energy I want to embrace this month. üß° This self portrait is already from 8 years ago, which is wild to me!  It‚Äôs still one of my very favourites I‚Äôve ever taken, to this day. ü•∞

‚ÄúA Place to Rest‚Äù

24/100 of my current self portrait project. üíö

I came across this moss-covered boulder in the woods a couple of weeks ago during one of the Rockies super warm Chinooks winds, which melted all the winter snow for a few days. It felt so surreal to wander around the forest and mountains of Banff National Park in what felt like early summer weather!  I haven‚Äôt taken a self portrait in the last several weeks just because it‚Äôs been sooooo freezing cold, so I took advantage of this extra warm day to forest bathe, listen to the birds, rest, soak in my surroundings and to create a new image to remember this feeling of February restfulness this year. And also to remember that spring really is on the horizon, even if it‚Äôs snowing again now. üòÇ

Care to join me in some majestic moody mountain gazing?  I could easily spend hours staring at the mountains (and indeed, I have been)... especially when the fog and clouds dance around between the peaks. üòç 

This month I‚Äôve been having extra fun capturing these scenes with my new lens, the @sonyalpha 70-200mm f/2.8 G Master II. ‚ÄúThe Essence of Lightness‚Äù

A self portrait taken at midnight in Iceland last summer (the time of endless light!). üíô

So far every morning this year I‚Äôve been deep diving into my journal, writing out and contemplating what it would be like to live lighter.  To cultivate an ease and lightness in my mind, to be less busy, to be more trusting in the unknown future.  To play more, and let my inner child lead me romping through the woodlands and meadows, inspired by my imagination. 

I thought I‚Äôd share this lil blurb I brain-barfed out onto the pages this morning. ü§ì‚¨áÔ∏è

‚ÄúThis year I want to let go of pressure.  Both the pressure I put on myself, and the pressure the societal world puts on us all. 

I let go of the pressure to be perfect. The pressure to look a certain way. The pressure to post every day. I let go of the pressure I put on myself to create better and better images, videos and paintings.

This year I embrace lightness. I celebrate imperfection, because when I allow myself and my creations to be made imperfectly with my mind open, it creates space for a world of new ideas, opportunities and surprise happenings I never would have dreamed up myself in my ‚Äúperfect world‚Äù.

This year I let my true essence take the seat of my mind and being. I take time to intentionally practice dwelling in my truest state - the state of complete trust, leading to peace and joyful lightness, where I feel the most myself. 

This year I allow myself to live. Not by someone else‚Äôs standards, and not by the standards I once thought I should hold over myself. 

I live by listening. I listen intently to what brings me a sense of joy, rightness and lightness. I listen to what I can give - what I can naturally offer and help bring out in others.

I live by being kind. I live in gratitude for the freedom I‚Äôm so, so, so incredibly fortunate to have access to.

I allow this freedom to be protected, nurtured and loved, to not let this gift be taken for granted or hijacked by the endless hustling pressures of the world.

This year I embrace lightness. I put my heart first, and I let love, trust and wonder lead the way down this path of life. This one chance we have to truly live.‚Äù ü§ç

Oh, 2023. ‚ù§Ô∏è 

There‚Äôs so many thoughts I could share from the past year, the ups and downs, the incredible things I‚Äôve seen and done, the hard struggles, overwhelm and work that came with it, the hopes and dreams for the future, the ongoing quest for a calmer mind, and many precious moments I wish could last forever. 

‚Ä¶but I‚Äôm going to simply end the year by sharing 10 slides that mean something to me in this moment. ü•∞

1. ‚ÄúEver Enduring‚Äù - a self portrait taken during a 400km hike across the mountains of Scotland in April.  One of the hardest and most beautiful experiences I‚Äôve had, and that I‚Äôm most proud of completing this year.

2. Backpacking in the Tombstone Mountains of the Yukon (still with the sword prop for photos, hehe). It felt so special to do a lot of hiking and camping with Pepper this year - he‚Äôll be 13 years old soon, so I‚Äôve been feeling extra aware/grateful for every adventure we have together. ü•π‚ù§Ô∏è

3.  @kristopherandres and I have spent more than half the year on the road, the trails or overseas this year. I can‚Äôt believe I get to share my dream nomadic life with this human. ü•∞

4.  A masterpiece by @stasia.schmidt portraying Kris, Pepper and myself.

5.  Kris trying to shake off a backwards waterfall.

6. I ate a lot of vegan lemon cake this year while sitting outside in the sun, and it was grand. I also never cared for lemon cake before this year, but I guess my tastebuds changed because now I can‚Äôt stop craving it. üòÇ

7.  My favourite novel I read this year.  I‚Äôve never empathized with the personality of a main character more - socially awkward but incredibly brave, her strength being kindness. 

8. Meeting @melissa_schaefer (creator of @magazine.mother ) in Copenhagen and seeing the magazine for my first time - with my photo on the cover! ü•∞

9. More precious moments with Pepper. A reminder to stay present.

10. Reflections from @chelseakauai ‚Äòs latest post - thoughts I‚Äôve been heavily deep diving into this past month, and am using to guide my priorities in 2024.  Perhaps these reflection prompts can help you, too. ‚ù§Ô∏èü•∞

Sending you all so much peace and love for the New Year! ‚ù§Ô∏è‚ù§Ô∏è‚ù§Ô∏è

‚ÄúHeart of the Solstice‚Äù

21/100 of my current self portrait project. üíö

Wishing you all a beautiful winter solstice today (at least, winter to everyone up here in the northern hemisphere!)

I have to admit that I absolutely, undoubtedly LOVE these long, dark and moody days (sorry to all my summer lovers out there!)‚Ä¶ and I sorta secretly long for winter solstice all year. üòÖ 

It‚Äôs a time where I somehow feel far less guilty about letting my mind and life slow down, where I can become like the trees and the bears in winter, resting quietly and hibernating from the world in my own little introverted cocoon.  It‚Äôs in the soft, quiet, candle-lit hours that I feel the most rested and at peace, and therefore more renewed and rekindled with creativity and short bursts of adventurous energy during the day - when these short hours of daylight are a gift, appreciated even more in the winter. ü•∞

Anyone else feel the same way? üïØÔ∏è

LEVEL ONE POSTPARTUM WORKOUT!

üî∫IMPORTANT: you MUST receive clearance from your doctor and if possible a women‚Äôs health physiotherapist, after 6 weeks postpartum before attempting this workout. Once you have that clearance, this can be your potential starting point. Begin basic, slow and easy. Reduce reps and sets as necessary and adjust to your individual level.
üëâ Repeat 2-3 times a week for 2-3 weeks or until level two feels suitable. 

Ensure you can engage and control your core / pelvic floor with all movements. If you‚Äôre struggling with this, try to see a women‚Äôs health physio in person to help you with that proper connection. 

Remember, there‚Äôs no race or competition. Be kind to yourself and don‚Äôt rush yourself or push your body before it‚Äôs ready. üíõ

ü§ù DM me for help with a fully personalised workout plan created for your current level and goals.

It‚Äôs not easy and I won‚Äôt sugar coat it, some days it works and some days it doesn‚Äôt. Some days they give me 8 minutes and some times I get a full 30. 
It was hard work getting myself into this routine but I didn‚Äôt give myself the choice.
I know I want to be active, I know I want my babies to see me being active. 
I know this phase of my life won‚Äôt last forever, and I can either make the most of it to focus on myself too, or I can sit back and watch the months turn into years where I‚Äôm still waiting. 

You can do this too mama. 
You just need to try. ü´∂

#postpartumfitness #postpregnancy #fitnessmotivation #fitness #workout #homeworkout #postpartumjourney #exercisemotivation

Your postpartum journey was not made to be an overnight road trip. It‚Äôs a long haul journey. But mama, you gotta show up for yourself. 
It‚Äôs tough work taking care of little people, and it‚Äôs even tougher work to find the time for YOU. I promise you will again one day. Any few moments in the day you can find to make yourself a priority, take it. 

This is almost 10 months of progress for me. 
That‚Äôs almost an entire year of waking up, trying my best, falling off track, but getting back on it again. 

It‚Äôs not easy, but give your body the same love, patience and care you gave it when it was growing a human. Be kind to yourself. But show up for yourself too üíõ
Hey, welcome üíõ LIKE this if you‚Äôre a fellow mumma trying to be your fittest and most confident self.

Remove your all or nothing mindset. 
The minute you allow yourself to just show up in whatever form you can each day, instead of being perfect, you take a tonne of weight off your shoulders. 

Let yourself do the workout that won‚Äôt get finished because you don‚Äôt have enough time. Just see how much you get done. 

Let yourself ‚Äòjust go for a walk‚Äô because your period cramps are too much for anything else. 

Let yourself focus on fuelling with good food and protein instead of a workout because you‚Äôre absolutely exhausted and just can‚Äôt manage it. 

Let yourself be flexible, let it not be perfect, but show up.

Before anyone asks, YES, you can eat pasta and reach your fitness goals. We don‚Äôt demonise foods here. 

High protein chicken pesto pasta üçÉ

What you‚Äôll need: 
- a jar of pesto (I used only 1/4 of this jar)
- Vetta smart protein pasta
- chicken thigh (I used 500 grams)
- olive oil (1-2 tablespoons) 
- crushed garlic (measure from the heart) 
- thickened cream (approx 150ml) 

What to do: 
- cook your pasta 
- heat your pan and oil, add garlic.
- cook chicken 90% 
- add pesto and cream 
- mix cook until chicken is fully done 
- add cooked pasta, mix and serve! 

Top with fresh basil or your favourite cheese. 
Done üëå

This made 4 portions for our family.

Because of Us

This morning I learned 
the English word gauze 
(finely woven medical cloth) 
comes from the Arabic word Ghazza 
because Gazans have been skilled weavers for centuries 

I wondered then 

how many of our wounds
have been dressed
because of them 

and how many of theirs
have been left open 
because of us

Elemental Connections Podcast
Episode 07 with @elliottsailors 
Diving into the topic of Authenticity.

I‚Äôm curious to know,
Do you feel like you are in touch with your most authentic self? ‚ù§Ô∏è

Finding Authenticity with Elliott Sailors - Episode 07 - Elemental Connections Podcast. 
During this episode I spoke with activist, model and Holistic Life Coach, Elliott Sailors. 
We discussed the theme of Authenticity, and how it‚Äôs the key to a finding satisfaction in life. 

We all have such a unique life journey. Everyone‚Äôs purpose and truth is theirs alone to discover. The important thing is learning to tune in to that inner knowing, and accepting ourselves in entirety. When we show up authentically, we inspire other to do the same, and are able to make deeper, and more meaningful connections. 
Our conversation was a lot of fun - it was open, fluid and very inspiring.
We hope you enjoy it as much as we did!

You can listen to the full episode via Spotify and Apple Podcast.

Spinach and ricotta shells üòã

This recipe is one of my favourite pasta dishes, so easy to make and a great one for entertaining too ü§åüèº

Ingredients:‚Ä®- 250g ricotta‚Ä®- 3 tbsp lemon juice‚Ä®- 100g chopped spinach‚Ä®- 1 tbsp minced garlic‚Ä®- 1 tsp salt‚Ä®- cracked pepper, to taste‚Ä®- 700g passata‚Ä®- handful of fresh basil leaves‚Ä®- 12 pasta shells‚Ä®- sprinkle of parmesan‚Ä®- 1 tbsp pine nuts

Method:
1. Preheat the oven to 180¬∞C fan-forced and place a large pot of water to boil over the stove, on high heat.
2. Once water is boiled, add the pasta shells to the pot. Cook as per packet instructions, ensuring not to overcook. Then, drain and rinse with cold water.
3. Add passata, fresh basil leaves, 1/2 tsp salt and pepper to a 30cm x 20cm baking dish and mix, spreading evenly.
4. Add ricotta, lemon, spinach, garlic, 1/2 tsp salt and pepper to a bowl and mix well to combine.
5. One-by-one, spoon approx 2 tbsp of the ricotta mixture into each shell and place into the baking dish. Repeat until shells and ricotta mixture are all used up.
6. Sprinkle with parmesan and pine nuts, and place into the oven to bake for 15-20 minutes, or until pine nuts and pasta shells begin to brown.
7. Serve hot & enjoy!

#vegetarian #vegetarianrecipe #pastarecipe #easyrecipe

Creamy tomato burrata pasta üçÖ

This pasta dish is such a great, simple meal for the Summertime! It‚Äôs super easy to make and absolutely delicious, hope you enjoy üòã

(Serves two)

Ingredients:‚Ä®- 2 tbsp butter‚Ä®- 1 garlic clove, minced‚Ä®- 1 whole chilli, diced‚Ä®- 250g cherry tomatoes‚Ä®- 2 tbsp tomato paste‚Ä®- 1 cup thickened cream‚Ä®- 250g pasta, cooked al dente‚Ä®- 150g burrata‚Ä®- fresh basil leaves, to serve‚Ä®- salt and pepper, to taste

Method:‚Ä®1. Cook your pasta and prepare garlic and chilli‚Ä®2. Place a large frying pan over medium-high heat on the stove, add butter and melt‚Ä®3. Add garlic, chilli and cherry tomatoes and fry for 3-4 minutes‚Ä®4. Add tomato paste, salt and pepper and continue frying for a further 3 minutes‚Ä®5. Add thickened cream and reduce heat to low-medium. Continue cooking, stirring occasionally, for a further 6-7 minutes or until the cherry tomatoes begin to break apart easily‚Ä®6. Add pre-cooked pasta and mix well with the sauce‚Ä®7. Tear burrata into chunks and pick fresh basil leaves. Add to the pasta‚Ä®8. Enjoy!

#burrata #burratarecipe #pastarecipe #summer #pasta #easymeals

Here‚Äôs a little throwback to one of my favourite recipes from my 3rd cookbook, Simple (Mostly) Vegan Kitchen ü´∂üèº

A super easy 5 minute choc self-saucing pudding!

(Serves two)

Ingredients:
Pudding:‚Ä®- 3 tbsp self raising flour‚Ä®- 3 tbsp coconut sugar‚Ä®- 1 + 1/2 tbsp cacao powder‚Ä®- 3 tbsp soy milk‚Ä®- 1/2 tsp vanilla extract‚Ä®- 2 tbsp olive oil

Sauce:‚Ä®- Pinch of salt‚Ä®- 3 tbsp boiling water‚Ä®- 1 tsp cacao powder‚Ä®- 1 tbsp coconut sugar

To serve:‚Ä®Vanilla ice-cream or pouring cream‚Ä®
Method:
1. Using a tall deep bowl, sieve in the flour, coconut sugar, and cacao powder.
2. Add the soy milk, vanilla extract, olive oil, and salt, whisk together to form a chocolate batter.
3. Sprinkle over the salt, cacao powder and coconut sugar. Top with boiling water.
4. Place in the microwave to cook for 90 seconds.
5. Remove and serve as desired.

Hope you enjoy!‚Ä®‚Ä®#vegan #veganrecipe #vegandessert #plantbased #dessert #5minrecipe #5mindessert #quickdessert

This simple katsu curry was a favourite for my family & I all winter! It‚Äôs super easy to make and sooo delicious, you can find these curry packets at your local supermarket here in Australia ü´∂üèº

Ingredients:‚Ä®- 1 tbsp cooking oil of choice‚Ä®- 1 brown onion, cut into chunky pieces‚Ä®- 1 carrot, cut in half lengthways and then sliced‚Ä®- 250g green beans‚Ä®- 1 head of broccoli, cut into florets‚Ä®- 750ml water‚Ä®- 1 Japanese curry mix packet (92g)‚Ä®- 2 vegan schnitzels, cooked as per packet instructions‚Ä®- Cooked white rice, to serve‚Ä®- Sesame seeds, to serve‚Ä®‚Ä®Method:‚Ä®1. This delicious winter minestrone recipe is from the slow cooker section of my 3rd cookbook, Simple Vegan Kitchen üçÖ

It is super hearty and warming, and filled with loads of nutritious veggies! Save this recipe so you can make it this winter ‚ò∫Ô∏è

Ingredients:‚Ä®- 1 tbsp olive oil‚Ä®- 2 celery stalks, sliced‚Ä®- 1 leek, white part only, halved lengthways and sliced‚Ä®- 1 carrot, quartered and sliced‚Ä®- 1 French shallot, finely chopped‚Ä®- 3 garlic cloves, crushed‚Ä®- 280g potatoes, cut into 1cm pieces‚Ä®- 3 bay leaves‚Ä®- 2 tsp dried Italian herbs‚Ä®- 400g can cannellini beans, rinsed and drained‚Ä®- 1.5 litres veggie stock‚Ä®- 2 x 400g cans crushed tomatoes‚Ä®- 1/4 tsp sea salt‚Ä®- freshly ground pepper to taste, plus extra to serve‚Ä®- 100g pasta shells‚Ä®- thick-cut bread, to serve (optional)‚Ä®‚Ä®Method:‚Ä®1. Turn your slow cooker to the saute setting‚Ä®2. Add the olive oil and, once it‚Äôs hot, add the celery, leek, carrot, shallot and garlic and saute for 2-3 minutes, until the vegetables have softened‚Ä®3. Switch the slow cooker to high, add the remaining ingredients except the pasta and mix lightly, then cover with the lid and cook for 3 hours‚Ä®4. Add the pasta shells to the slow cooker and stir them through. Cover with the lid and continue to cook on high for another hour or until the pasta shells are cooked through‚Ä®5. Serve hot, with a good sprinkling of freshly ground black pepper and some thick-cut bread on the side, if desired

Enjoy!

This baked shakshuka is a delicious low-effort vegetarian brekky that is perfect in the cooler months! I love serving it with toasted sourdough or pita bread. Enjoy! üòãü§åüèº PS there‚Äôs a vegan version in my latest cookbook

Serves 2

Ingredients:‚Ä®- 400g can chopped tomatoes‚Ä®- 2 tbsp finely diced red onion‚Ä®- 2 garlic cloves, crushed‚Ä®- 1/4 tsp cayenne pepper (or to taste)‚Ä®- 1 tsp smoked paprika‚Ä®- 1/2 tsp ground cumin‚Ä®- 1/2 tsp sea salt‚Ä®- black pepper, to taste‚Ä®- 2 eggs‚Ä®- 2 cubes feta‚Ä®- 2 tsp olive oil‚Ä®- parsley, to serve‚Ä®- bread, to serve‚Ä®‚Ä®Method:‚Ä®1. Preheat the oven to 200¬∞C fan-forced‚Ä®2. Place the tomatoes, onion, garlic, spices, salt and pepper in a 20cm x 15cm baking dish and stir to combine. Transfer to the oven and bake for 10 minutes, then remove from the oven.‚Ä®3. Make 2 indents in the tomato mixture and carefully crack the eggs in (it may be easier to crack these into 2 seperate bowls first, and pour in). Drizzle with olive oil, crumble the feta on top. Place back in the oven to bake for a further 14-16 minutes.‚Ä®4. Remove shakshuka from the oven and top with parsley. Serve hot with bread, and enjoy!

This delicious, creamy ramen is perfect in the cooler months üçú Packed full of veggies and tofu for protein, it‚Äôs also super easy to make üå± This recipe is on page 70 of my 3rd cookbook, Simple Vegan Kitchen. Enjoy!

Serves 2 - 4

Ingredients:
1 tbsp oil, any kind for frying
1 cup/100 g finely sliced shiitake mushrooms
1 x 400g can of corn, drained
1 pak choy bunch, roughly chopped
2 spring onions, finely sliced
300g soft tofu, drained and cut into 1-2cm cubes
200g ramen noodles (GF rice noodle optional)
1 nori sheet, shredded
Broth:
1 veggie stock cube
1.5 tbsp miso paste
1 tbsp soy sauce
2.5 cup oat milk (GF sub for cashew/soy milk, I used Vitasoy oat milk)
1.5 cup boiling water
1 tbsp sesame oil
Optional
Sriracha 
Japanese seasoning 

Method:
1. Place a large pot over medium - high heat, add oil, once hot, add mushrooms and fry for 2 minutes, strirring occasionally. Add corn and white portion of spring onion. Fry for further 2 minutes.
2. Place another large pot filled with water over high heat, bring water to the boil and cook noodles as per packet instruction.
3. Slice pak choy into quarters and fry over medium heat, until lightly crispy. Set to the side.
4. Crumble the vegetable stock cube into a bowl with the boiling water, add miso paste and stir to dissolve, add to the pot of vegetables, along with the oat milk and soy sauce, bring to the boil and then remove from heat. Stir in sesame oil.
5. Drain noodles and place in the bottom of bowls along with tofu cubes.
6. Ladle the veggie broth across bowls, covering the noodles and tofu.
7. Top with pak choy, remaining spring onion and shredded nori, and if you like some spice, add sriracha sauce or shichimi togarshi seasoning.

#veganrecipe #plantbasedrecipe #plantbased #vegetarianrecipe #veganramen #ramenrecipe

Once cool, place lid on the jar and store in the pantry. Enjoy as desired!‚Ä®‚Ä®#hothoney #hothoneyrecipe #recipe #vegetarianrecipe #honeyrecipe #easyrecipe
